the agenda for TC Early Stage \u2014 Operations &#038; Fundraising"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">As an early-stage founder, how do you identify the right investors? Or know how to hire the best possible team to set up your company for growth? Should you bootstrap, and if so, how do you do it successfully? How do you nail virtual pitch meetings? What about product-market fit? Board construction and good governance? How do you make sound financial decisions both for your company and yourself?<\/p>\n<p id=\"speakable-summary\">You\u2019ve got questions. <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-early-stage-2021-part-1\/?promo=agendapost\">TechCrunch Early Stage<\/a> will have answers for you on April 1 and 2.<\/p>\n<p>At the virtual event, we\u2019re bringing together some of the most seasoned operators in the fields of legal, recruiting, product, data security and sales to help you find your way through a tactical quagmire to the bright light of success at the end of the tunnel.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Of course, the show will cover more than operational challenges. We also have many, many\u00a0sessions around fundraising, from how to think about raising your Series A to how to get an investors attention.<br \/>\nIf you\u2019re in the midst of building a company, this show is worth making time for. Plus, audience members will be able to ask expert speakers their own questions to in each and every breakout session.<\/p>\n<h2>Finding Your Product-Market Fit (Sean Lane \u2014 Olive AI)<\/h2>\n<p>Olive AI founder and CEO is no stranger to the pivot. Hear how he practiced patience in the search for product-market fit, how he knew it when he finally found it and tactics he used to build on it.<\/p>\n<h2>How to Get an Investor&#8217;s Attention (Marlon Nichols \u2014 MaC Venture Capital)<\/h2>\n<p>Marlon Nichols is an expert in early-stage investments, having invested in countless successful ventures such as Gimlet Media, MongoDB, Thrive Market, PlayVS, Fair, Wonderschool and Finesse. Right now, there is more seed-stage fundraising than ever before, and Marlon will speak on how to get noticed by investors, how to grow your business and how to survive in the crowded, competitive space of tech startups. He will provide insights on how to network, craft a great pitch and target the best investors for your success.<\/p>\n<h2>How to Nail Your Virtual Pitch Meeting (Melissa Bradley \u2014 Ureeka)<\/h2>\n<p>The rules of the pitch meeting have changed. Instead of traveling across the country, wasting time in planes, trains and automobiles, founders can take upward of 30 meetings in a day from the comfort of their home. Entrepreneur and VC Melissa Bradley will outline how to make the most of that half hour on Zoom and lock in the next one.<\/p>\n<h2>10 Things NOT To Do When You Are Starting a Company (Leah Solivan \u2014 Fuel Capital)<\/h2>\n<p>With voices across the internet giving their two cents on how to run a great business, Fuel Capital&#8217;s Leah Solivan, who was CEO at TaskRabbit for eight years, will share a list of things that a founder should NOT do. Avoid the pitfalls that could break your momentum, or worst case, your company and ask Solivan your own questions.<\/p>\n<h2>How To Get Into An Accelerator (Neal Sales-Griffin \u2014 Techstars)<\/h2>\n<p>Accelerators provide an incredible launch pad for early-stage startups, offering a built-in network, accessible advisors, and of course, capital. But first, you&#8217;ve got to be accepted. Hear Techstars&#8217; Neal Sales-Griffin outline how to get into an accelerator and make the most of the experience.<\/p>\n<h2>4 Things To Think About Before Raising a Series A (Bucky Moore \u2014 Kleiner Perkins)<\/h2>\n<p>Founders looking to raise Series A capital know that it&#8217;s an entirely different ball game than seed-stage funding. Hear Kleiner Perkins partner Bucky Moore outline the most important ways to mentally prepare for heading into Series A fundraising.<\/p>\n<h2>How to Build Your Early Team for Future Growth (Sarah Smith \u2014 Bain Capital Ventures)<\/h2>\n<p>More than your investors, or even you as a founder, your early employees will have a tremendous influence on the trajectory of your company. You hire them, and oftentimes, they hire everyone else. Hear Bain Capital Ventures partner Sarah Smith talk through how to recruit a top-notch early team that sets your startup up for future growth.<\/p>\n<h2>Contracts, Cap Tables and other Legal Questions (Dawn Belt \u2014 Fenwick)<\/h2>\n<p>No matter the industry, your startup requires legal help. Whether it&#8217;s building out the cap table, writing up contracts, understanding the laws around hiring or simply feeling secure with a TOS. Whatever the question, Fenwick partner Dawn Belt has the answer.<\/p>\n<h2>Finance for Founders (Alexa von Tobel \u2014 Inspired Capital)<\/h2>\n<p>As a founder, you not only have to master your company&#8217;s finances, you also have to tackle your own personal finances. Managing your money as a founder comes with a unique set of questions (see: QSBS). Leveraging her expertise from LearnVest and as a Certified Financial Planner\u2122, Alexa will share financial planning best practices so founders can remove this layer of stress from the pressure of building a business.<\/p>\n<h2>Leadership Culture and Good Governance (David Easton \u2014 Generation Investment Management)<\/h2>\n<p>David Easton is a growth-stage partner at Generation Investment Management with portfolio companies that include Asana, Andela, Gusto and Docusign, among others. Easton will talk through how to choose your board and foster a leadership culture that keeps sustainable, good governance top of mind.<\/p>\n<h2>Building and Leading a Sales Team (Ryan Azus \u2014 Zoom)<\/h2>\n<p>Contrary to popular opinion, even the very best products don&#8217;t sell themselves. Salespeople do. Hear from Zoom&#8217;s chief revenue officer, at the helm of the company&#8217;s sales team during the biggest period of growth of any software company ever, lay out how to build a stellar sales team.<\/p>\n<h2>The All-22 View (Eghosa Omoigui \u2014 EchoVC Partners)<\/h2>\n<p>Improving line of sight and dynamic field of play aperture is rarely discussed but hugely important. Great founders, operators and investors have an understanding of playbooks on both sides of the ball. We&#8217;ll talk through lessons and some ideas on how to build muscle memory and skillsets so that founders never lose perspective when it&#8217;s time to make a big decision.<\/p>\n<p>And we&#8217;ll also have some great sessions from our partners too!<\/p>\n<h2>Creating and Protecting IP Value in Connection with VC Financings (brought to you by <a href=\"http:\/\/www.perkinscoie.com\/\">Perkins Coie<\/a>)<\/h2>\n<p>How do venture capital investors value formal intellectual property (IP) rights in connection with a decision to fund a technology or life sciences startup? How do they conduct IP due diligence? How do investors and founders, post-funding, ensure their startups are pursuing an IP strategy that optimizes exit valuation for all? Perkins Coie partners Michael Glenn (Patent Prosecution) and Matt Oshinsky (Emerging Companies Venture Capital) will be joined alongside a seasoned venture capitalist to discuss these and other questions regarding safeguarding IP rights and maximizing the value of all technology development activities.<\/p>\n<h2>Scientist Entrepreneurs \u2014 Scaling Breakout Engineering Biology Companies (brought to you by <a href=\"https:\/\/www.mayfield.com\/\">Mayfield<\/a>)<\/h2>\n<p>Biology as technology will reinvent trillion dollar industries and enhance human and planetary evolution. In this session, two early-stage investors and company builders, Arvind Gupta and Ursheet Parikh, will be in conversation with leading author and seed investor Po Bronson, managing director of IndieBio. They will share their playbook on scaling startups touching upon three seminal areas that influence trajectory\u2014 fundraising, hiring and product design. Their insights will draw on their experience with companies including ingredients-as-a-service leader Geltor, which raised a $91 million Series B in 2020; CRISPR platform Mammoth Biosciences, whose dream team includes Nobel Laureate co-founder Jennifer Doudna; and Endpoint Health, started by the founding team of GeneWEAVE (acquired by Roche) and former YC Bio Partner Diego Rey, which is designing a new class of therapeutic products that focus on hospital conditions that kill as many people as cancer.<\/p>\n<h2>Using Fast Feedback to Make Higher-Confidence Decisions and Accelerate the Dev Process (brought to you by <a href=\"https:\/\/www.usertesting.com\/\">UserTesting<\/a>)<\/h2>\n<p>We&#8217;ll discuss how to use fast feedback methodologies to make high-confidence product decisions based on objective customer data in real time, without slowing the dev process. Quickly diagnose problems, settle disputes, reduce the risk of rework and iterate faster. This session will include real-world case studies.<\/p>\n<h2>An M&amp;A Playbook for Startup Founders: Lessons from Google and Microsoft (brought to you by <a href=\"http:\/\/www.meruscap.com\/\">Merus Capital<\/a>)<\/h2>\n<p>One of the most important decisions a founding team can make is when to consider selling the company to a strategic buyer. In this session, learn the tactics for approaching acquirers, avoiding common pitfalls and maximizing the likelihood of achieving an eye-popping valuation. Hear from Sean Dempsey, founding partner of Merus Capital who spent 10 years leading acquisitions for Google and Microsoft, and Dave Sobota, VP of Corporate Development at Instacart and former M&amp;A leader at Google.<\/p>\n<h2>Why Founders Should Adopt OKRs Now? (brought to you by <a href=\"https:\/\/dell.to\/TechCrunch\">Dell for Entrepreneurs<\/a>)<\/h2>\n<p>Execution is key to a startup&#8217;s survival and growth especially when it comes to fast-moving software and technology products. Being in the tricky intersection of investors, customers and employees, a founder needs to balance priorities, align teams and create a visionary product that works. Moreover, in this age of hyperfeedback loops and changing business models, the founder has to be agile enough to absorb and quickly react to changes in the product roadmap and consumer needs. OKRs \u2014 a toolkit used mostly by engineering and product teams is more than relevant now for founders of all kinds to embrace. Join the session to learn the history of OKRs, what they are about and witness case studies of successful real-life adoption.<\/p>\n<h2>Naming and Protecting Your Company\u2019s Intellectual Property (brought to you by <a href=\"http:\/\/www.brainbase.com\/\">Brainbase<\/a>)<\/h2>\n<p>You have an idea for a game-changing product or service \u2014 what do you call it? Once you\u2019ve picked a name, how do you make sure nobody else is using it? Is the domain and Twitter handle available? Brainbase makes it easy for anyone to file a trademark without a lawyer and instantly own your brand across all channels. In this session, Brainbase co-founder and CEO Nate Cavanaugh will explain the importance of owning your company\u2019s trademark, both for brand protection and for fundraising due diligence.<\/p>\n<h2>Nailing the Little Things: How Startups Can Achieve Operational Excellence from &#8220;Day One&#8221; (brought to you by <a href=\"https:\/\/www.bcapgroup.com\/\">B Capital Group<\/a>)<\/h2>\n<p>The early days of launching a company can be a whirlwind for founding teams as unexpected challenges and opportunities require flexibility, agility and speed. But implementing a few key operating best practices and processes early can be a crucial part of a startup&#8217;s success or failure when it prepares for rapid growth. Join partners from B Capital Group, a multistage global investor, to learn about the most important things you can do to set your startup up for success early in your journey, and what will be most important to investors as you raise your Seed, A and B funding rounds. Speakers include Howard Morgan, chairman of B Capital Group and co-founder of First Round Capital, and partners Karen Page (formerly of Box) and Gabe Greenbaum (formerly of Pritzker Group).<\/p>\n<p>This year, we\u2019ve <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/03\/announcing-the-tc-early-stage-pitch-off\/\">added a pitch-off<\/a> on day 2 of <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-early-stage-2021-part-1\/?promo=agendapost\">TC Early Stage<\/a>, showcasing interesting startups from a variety of sectors. All-star judges will give their feedback live. You don\u2019t want to miss it! And if you&#8217;re interested in pitching, you can still <a href=\"https:\/\/tc692057.typeform.com\/to\/jNejpAvG\">apply to pitch by tomorrow, March 9<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>Of course,\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-early-stage-2021-part-1\/?promo=quorapost&amp;display=true\">TC Early Stage<\/a> dual event ticket holders will get access to both events (April 1-2 and July 8-9) and have access to 2x the content that comes out of the event live or on demand. Plus, you can take advantage of additional savings with <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-early-stage-2021-part-1\/?promo=quorapost&amp;display=true\">early-bird pricing<\/a> on dual event tickets until March 26!<\/p>\n<p>Mercenary CEOs know all too well that this is about the most bang you can get for your buck. Period. Grab <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-early-stage-2021-part-1\/?promo=quorapost&amp;display=true\">your ticket now and save up to Early Stage 2021 - Operations &amp; Fundraising","slug":"tc-early-stage-2021-part-1","taxonomy":"tc_event","rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event\/576831922"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/tc_event"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event\/576715145"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tc_event=576831922"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_events?tc_event=576831922"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tc_event=576831922"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}]]}},{"id":2121522,"date":"2021-03-08T11:34:40","date_gmt":"2021-03-08T19:34:40","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2121522"},"modified":"2021-03-08T13:00:49","modified_gmt":"2021-03-08T21:00:49","slug":"from-electric-charging-to-supply-chain-management-inmotion-ventures-preps-jaguar-for-a-sustainable-future","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/from-electric-charging-to-supply-chain-management-inmotion-ventures-preps-jaguar-for-a-sustainable-future\/","title":{"rendered":"From electric charging to supply chain management, InMotion Ventures preps Jaguar for a sustainable future"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">Since <a href=\"https:\/\/www.inmotionventures.com\/\">InMotion Ventures<\/span><\/a>, the independent investment and incubation initiative set up by <a href=\"https:\/\/www.jaguarlandrover.com\/\">Jaguar Land Rover<\/a>, launched in 2016 the firm has focused on backing companies across the mobility space broadly. Its 15 active investments run the gamut from autonomous vehicles, to car insurance tech, to ride-sharing, and travel planning, but increasingly the firm is focusing its efforts on vehicle electrification and sustainable supply chains.<\/p>\n<p>\t<div class=\"article-block block--pullout block--right\">\n\t\t<blockquote>\n\t\t\tAs the mobility market moves to embrace electrification, InMotion wants to make sure its portfolio is in the mix.\t\t\t\t\t<\/blockquote>\n\t<\/div>\n\t<\/p>\n<p>That&#8217;s evident from its most recent investment in <a href=\"https:\/\/www.circulor.com\/\">Circulor<\/a>, a company that monitors supply chains from raw material inputs to finished outputs with an eye toward sustainable sourcing.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;<span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">As an OEM nowadays it\u2019s increasingly important to have increasing transparency and visibility into how all of those materials have been sourced,&#8221; said the firm&#8217;s managing director, Sebastian Peck. Circulor already has a strong footprint in the automotive industry, Peck said, and is working with a major oil company on tracing the share of recycled plastics that have come from that provider. &#8220;It has applications across any industry.&#8221;<\/span><\/p>\n<p>Jaguar Land Rover is also using Circulor&#8217;s technology to track a material that&#8217;s being used in the interior of one of the company&#8217;s vehicles, Peck said. The stealthy project hasn&#8217;t been publicly revealed yet, but the company has worked with a university and supplier to trace the material from its point of origin to the finished product.<\/p>\n<p>Sustainable supply chains aren&#8217;t the only priorities Peck laid out in a recent interview with TechCrunch.<\/p>\n<p>As the mobility market moves to embrace electrification, InMotion wants to make sure its portfolio is in the mix and Peck said it would be looking to make investments in a number of different areas around electric vehicles and batteries.<\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">&#8220;We have looked at a number of companies who are developing new battery chemistries. We haven\u2019t made an investment yet,&#8221; Peck said. &#8220;We don\u2019t have a deep enough insight into the IP portfolios of the big battery suppliers to really be able to reliably benchmark those new chemistries. We have not had enough conviction to make an investment or back a particular company. From a value chain it is two or three steps away from us. It\u2019s a space we\u2019re looking at.&#8221;<\/span><\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_1947767\" style=\"width: 2310px\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-1947767\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"breakout wp-image-1947767 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/Jaguar-Land-Rover-Mobility-Concept-1.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"2300\" height=\"1449\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/Jaguar-Land-Rover-Mobility-Concept-1.jpg 2300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/Jaguar-Land-Rover-Mobility-Concept-1.jpg?resize=150,95 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/Jaguar-Land-Rover-Mobility-Concept-1.jpg?resize=300,189 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/Jaguar-Land-Rover-Mobility-Concept-1.jpg?resize=768,484 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/Jaguar-Land-Rover-Mobility-Concept-1.jpg?resize=680,428 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/Jaguar-Land-Rover-Mobility-Concept-1.jpg?resize=1536,968 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/Jaguar-Land-Rover-Mobility-Concept-1.jpg?resize=2048,1290 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/Jaguar-Land-Rover-Mobility-Concept-1.jpg?resize=50,32 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 2300px) 100vw, 2300px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-1947767\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Jaguar Land Rover<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p><div class=\"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>&#8220;Obviously, we venture beyond electrification into autonomous vehicles and connectivity. There will be a lot of value creation once OEMs are able to surface their APIs.&#8221;<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":59254947,"featured_media":1660447,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"outcome":"","status":"","crunchbase_tag":0,"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"3b5a19f6-7608-3448-960a-faf27dc16c50"},"categories":[449557096,20429,17396,2401,35394854],"tags":[576856615,378477,576597588,448640155,576856403,449557042],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[576796356],"tc_event":[],"jetpack_featured_media_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/GettyImages-952193106.jpg","shortlink":"https:\/\/tcrn.ch\/3kYmG2Y","rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"premiumContent":true,"premiumCutoffPercent":0.49,"featured":false,"subtitle":"","seoTitle":"","seoDescription":"","tc_cb_mapping":[],"associatedEvent":null,"event":null,"authors":[59254947],"hide_featured_image":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2121522"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/types\/post"}],"replies":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/comments?post=2121522"}],"version-history":[{"count":9,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2121522\/revisions"}],"predecessor-version":[{"id":2122536,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2121522\/revisions\/2122536"}],"authors":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/59254947"}],"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/edit":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-admin\/post.php?post=2121522&action=edit"}],"author":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/59254947"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/media\/1660447"}],"wp:attachment":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrun Shieber","url":"","description":"","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/author\/jonathan-shieber\/","slug":"jonathan-shieber","avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\/\/secure.gravatar.com\/avatar\/a81fccb1686f7db1afd1c14a019b5bc1?s=24&d=identicon&r=g","48":"https:\/\/secure.gravatar.com\/avatar\/a81fccb1686f7db1afd1c14a019b5bc1?s=48&d=identicon&r=g","96":"https:\/\/secure.gravatar.com\/avatar\/a81fccb1686f7db1afd1c14a019b5bc1?s=96&d=identicon&r=g"},"links":{"twitter":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/jshieber","linkedin":"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/pub\/jonathan-shieber\/0\/baa\/b27","crunchbase":"https:\/\/www.crunchbase.com\/person\/jonathan-shieber"},"position":"Writer","cbDescription":"<p>Jonathan is an editor at TechCrunch. Previously he worked as a senior reporter for Dow Jones & Co., covering venture capital and private equity investment from New York and Shanghai. Peck","slug":"sebastian-peck","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576856403"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576856403"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576856403"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576856403"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576856403"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":449557042,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/startups\/","name":"Startups","slug":"startups","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449557042"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449557042"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[{"id":576796356,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/extracrunch\/market-analysis\/","name":"Market Analysis","slug":"market-analysis","taxonomy":"tc_ec_category","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category\/576796356"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/tc_ec_category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tc_ec_category=576796356"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[]]}},{"id":2122238,"date":"2021-03-08T07:15:02","date_gmt":"2021-03-08T15:15:02","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2122238"},"modified":"2021-03-08T10:58:03","modified_gmt":"2021-03-08T18:58:03","slug":"mcafee-sells-enterprise-biz-to-symphony-technology-group-for-4b","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/mcafee-sells-enterprise-biz-to-symphony-technology-group-for-4b\/","title":{"rendered":"McAfee sells enterprise biz to Symphony Technology Group for $4B"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Security firm <a href=\"http:\/\/www.mcafee.com\">McAfee<\/a> announced this morning that it will be selling its enterprise business to a consortium led by the private equity firm <a href=\"https:\/\/stgpartners.com\/\">Symphony Technology Group<\/a> for $4 billion.<\/p>\n<p>It should pair well with RSA, another enterprise-focused security company <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/02\/18\/dell-sells-rsa-to-consortium-led-by-symphony-technology-group-for-over-2b\/\">the private equity firm purchased<\/a> last February for $2 billion.<\/p>\n<p>McAfee President and Chief Executive Officer Peter Leav says that his company has decided to direct the firm&#8217;s resources to the consumer side of the business. &#8220;This transaction will allow McAfee to singularly focus on our consumer business and to accelerate our strategy to be a leader in personal security for consumers,&#8221; he said in a statement.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>The company has been making some moves in the last year, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.bloombergquint.com\/business\/mcafee-ipo-is-said-to-raise-740-million-in-return-to-market#:~:text=the%20stock%20market.-,(Bloomberg)%20%2D%2D%20McAfee%20Corp.,Wednesday%2C%20according%20to%20a%20statement.\">returning to the public markets<\/a> after a decade as a private company. In January, the company <a href=\"https:\/\/www.channele2e.com\/business\/talent\/mcafee-layoffs-2021-staff-cuts\/\">reportedly laid off a couple of hundred employees<\/a> and shut down its software development center in Tel Aviv.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"ULnNqFGV53\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/06\/02\/cybersecurity-vc-survey-investing-valuations\/\">12 top cybersecurity VCs discuss investing, valuations and no-go zones<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;12 top cybersecurity VCs discuss investing, valuations and no-go zones&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/06\/02\/cybersecurity-vc-survey-investing-valuations\/embed\/#?secret=ULnNqFGV53\" data-secret=\"ULnNqFGV53\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>Although Symphony did not point directly to the RSA acquisition, the two investments create a large combined legacy security business for the firm, both of which have strong brand recognition, but might have lost some of their edge to more modern competitors in the marketplace.<\/p>\n<p>Looking at McAfee&#8217;s <a href=\"https:\/\/ir.mcafee.com\/static-files\/86dedd74-00e2-4f57-8995-5fef120cef51\">latest earning&#8217;s report<\/a>, Q42020, which the company reported on February 24, 2021, the consumer business grew at a much brisker rate than the enterprise side of the house. The former was up 23% YoY, while the latter grew at a far slower 5% rate.<\/p>\n<p>As for the entire year, the company reported $2.9 billion in total FY2020 revenue, up 10% YoY. That broke down to $1.6 billion in consumer net revenue up 20% YoY, and $1.3 billion in enterprise net revenue, an increase of just 1% for the full year.<\/p>\n<p>The company has a complex history, starting life in the 1980s selling firewall software. It eventually went public before being <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2010\/08\/19\/intel-buys-cyber-security-giant-mcafee-for-7-68-billion-in-cash\/\">purchased by Intel for $7.7 billion<\/a> in 2010 and going private again. In 2014, <a href=\"https:\/\/money.cnn.com\/2014\/01\/07\/technology\/security\/intel-mcafee\/index.html\">the company changed names<\/a> to Intel Security before <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2017\/04\/03\/intel-security-is-mcafee-again\/#:~:text=Today%2C%20Intel%20is%20officially%20inking,retain%20a%2049%20percent%20stake.\">Intel sold a majority stake to TPG in 2017<\/a> for $4.2 billion and changed the name back to McAfee.<\/p>\n<p>The transaction is expected to close by the end of this year, subject to regulatory oversight.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"Ar0yugytYg\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/02\/18\/dell-sells-rsa-to-consortium-led-by-symphony-technology-group-for-over-2b\/\">Dell sells RSA to consortium led by Symphony Technology Group for over $2B<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Dell sells RSA to consortium led by Symphony Technology Group for over $2B&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/02\/18\/dell-sells-rsa-to-consortium-led-by-symphony-technology-group-for-over-2b\/embed\/#?secret=Ar0yugytYg\" data-secret=\"Ar0yugytYg\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<hr \/>\n<p><em><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/26\/techcrunch-early-stage-is-the-startup-bootcamp-youve-always-needed\/?tpcc=ECTW2020\">Early Stage<\/a> is the premier &#8220;how-to&#8221; event for startup entrepreneurs and investors. You\u2019ll hear firsthand how some of the most successful founders and VCs build their businesses, raise money and manage their portfolios. We\u2019ll cover every aspect of company building: Fundraising, recruiting, sales, product-market fit, PR, marketing and brand building. Each session also has audience participation built-in &#8212; there\u2019s ample time included for audience questions and discussion.<\/em><\/p>\n<p>\t<iframe\n\t\t\tid=\"wpcom-iframe-dde292b93a5f3017145419dd51bb9fce\"\n\t\t\twidth=\"99%\"\n\t\t\theight=\"1500\"\n\t\t\tsrc=\"https:\/\/tcprotectedembed.com\/protected-iframe\/dde292b93a5f3017145419dd51bb9fce\"\n\t\t\tscrolling=\"true\"\n\t\t\tframeborder=\"0\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"wpcom-protected-iframe\"\n\t>\n\t<\/iframe>\n\t<script Technology Group","slug":"symphony-technology-group","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576738629"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576738629"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576738629"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576738629"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576738629"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2122324,"date":"2021-03-08T09:38:40","date_gmt":"2021-03-08T17:38:40","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2122324"},"modified":"2021-03-08T12:07:14","modified_gmt":"2021-03-08T20:07:14","slug":"apple-teams-with-common-sense-media-to-curate-podcasts-for-kids","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/apple-teams-with-common-sense-media-to-curate-podcasts-for-kids\/","title":{"rendered":"Apple teams with Common Sense Media to curate podcasts for kids"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Apple announced this morning it&#8217;s teaming up with Common Sense Media to curate a selection of kid-friendly podcasts in the U.S. in light of what appears to be growing interest in spoken-word entertainment among families. That interest, in part, may have been prompted by the pandemic and parents&#8217; desire to reduce kids&#8217; screen time for entertainment.<\/p>\n<p>Via a new website at <a href=\"http:\/\/apple.co\/showsforkids\">Apple.co\/showsforkids<\/a> (which launches Apple Podcasts), Apple has collaborated with Common Sense Media to group podcasts by age group as well as by theme. At launch, the collection features creators like Tinkercast, American Public Media, Gen-Z Media, Pinna, Tumble, Highlights, WNYC Studios, Rebel Girls and Nickelodeon, among others.<\/p>\n<p>In addition to groups by age, there are also four thematic collections available: <em>Common Sense Media Picks<\/em>, which are all-time family favorites; <em>One More!,<\/em> which features mysterious tales and action-packed dramas; <em>Kids Know Best<\/em>, which feature shows picked by kids themselves; and <em>Story Time<\/em>, which are story-driven shows.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2122364\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2122364\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2122364\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Screen-Shot-2021-03-08-at-12.28.04-PM.jpg?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"483\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Screen-Shot-2021-03-08-at-12.28.04-PM.jpg 2794w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Screen-Shot-2021-03-08-at-12.28.04-PM.jpg?resize=150,107 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Screen-Shot-2021-03-08-at-12.28.04-PM.jpg?resize=300,213 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Screen-Shot-2021-03-08-at-12.28.04-PM.jpg?resize=768,545 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Screen-Shot-2021-03-08-at-12.28.04-PM.jpg?resize=680,483 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Screen-Shot-2021-03-08-at-12.28.04-PM.jpg?resize=1536,1091 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Screen-Shot-2021-03-08-at-12.28.04-PM.jpg?resize=2048,1454 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Screen-Shot-2021-03-08-at-12.28.04-PM.jpg?resize=50,36 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2122364\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> screenshot of Apple Podcasts<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>The site will be updated monthly to feature new and popular shows and to introduce timely collections around historical and cultural moments, like Women&#8217;s History Month or Back to School ideas, Apple says.<\/p>\n<p>The company also notes the selection of shows is curated using the same sort of research-backed approach that Common Sense Media applies to other entertainment, like TV shows, movies, books, apps and games.<\/p>\n<p>The launch follows <a href=\"https:\/\/www.macrumors.com\/2021\/03\/04\/apple-launches-apple-for-kids-support-page\/\">Apple&#8217;s recent debut of an &#8220;Apple for Kids&#8221; website<\/a> that helps parents set up devices for kids and learn about Family Sharing options, highlighting an increased interest in catering to the needs of families.<\/p>\n<p>But unlike with kids&#8217; use of Apple devices, the current market for kids&#8217; podcasts is small &#8212; none of Apple&#8217;s top 100 podcasts are directed toward kids, for example.<\/p>\n<p>However, industry experts believe the kids market may grow alongside the overall adult podcast market. Plus, as <a href=\"https:\/\/morningconsult.com\/2020\/11\/10\/podcasts-kids-parents-polling\/\">Morning Consult recently reported<\/a>, the COVID-19 pandemic has helped drive new interest in the audio format as parents struggled to keep kids entertained at home.<\/p>\n<p>Case in point: one leading kids&#8217; podcast, &#8220;Wow in the World&#8221; by NPR, saw a 94% increase in downloads in the 13 weeks post-COVID compared with pre-COVID, the report said.<\/p>\n<p>In another recent analysis, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.nationalpublicmedia.com\/insights\/reports\/the-spoken-word-audio-report\/\">NPR&#8217;s 2020 Spoken Word Audio Report<\/a> found that 15% of U.S. adults were now listening to children&#8217;s spoken word audio &#8212; an indication that many parents were already co-listening with kids. In addition, research from <a href=\"https:\/\/www.kidslisten.org\/\">Kids Listen<\/a>, a nonprofit advocacy group for kids&#8217; podcasts, found that 89% of kids who listen to podcasts are ages 8 or under, <a href=\"https:\/\/morningconsult.com\/2020\/11\/10\/podcasts-kids-parents-polling\/\">Morning Consult pointed out.<\/a><\/p>\n<p>Apple, it&#8217;s worth noting, has been rumored to be considering a new podcast subscription service to challenge Spotify, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.theinformation.com\/articles\/apple-plans-podcasting-subscription-service-in-threat-to-spotify\">The Information reported year earlier this year.<\/a> In the weeks since that report, Apple has seemingly begun to pay more attention to the format, having <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/19\/apples-new-editorial-franchise-apple-podcasts-spotlight-to-highlight-interesting-creators\/\">launched a new editorial franchise, Apple Podcasts Spotlight,<\/a> to highlight interesting creators.<\/p>\n<p>Adding kids&#8217; programing could play into Apple&#8217;s future ambitions, perhaps, as 64% of parents who listen to podcasts said they&#8217;re likely to purchase a paid subscription to podcasts for their kids.<\/p>\n<p>The new collection is live in the U.S. in Apple Podcasts.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"qJtFDakAWh\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/08\/04\/more-thoughts-on-growing-podcasts\/\">More thoughts on growing\u00a0podcasts<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;More thoughts on growing\u00a0podcasts&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/08\/04\/more-thoughts-on-growing-podcasts\/embed\/#?secret=qJtFDakAWh\" data-secret=\"qJtFDakAWh\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Apple announced this morning it&#8217;s teaming up with Common Sense Media to curate a selection of kid-friendly podcasts in the U.S. in light of what appears to be growing interest in spoken-word entertainment among families. That interest, in part, may have been prompted by the pandemic and parents&#8217; desire to reduce kids&#8217; screen time for m\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=518"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=518"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=518"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2121723,"date":"2021-03-08T07:50:38","date_gmt":"2021-03-08T15:50:38","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2121723"},"modified":"2021-03-08T11:53:25","modified_gmt":"2021-03-08T19:53:25","slug":"investors-discuss-alt-financing-and-the-role-of-venture-capital","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/investors-discuss-alt-financing-and-the-role-of-venture-capital\/","title":{"rendered":"Investors discuss alt-financing and the role of venture capital"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">There are so many ways to secure capital for your startup beyond traditional venture capital, from crowdfunding to debt financings to revenue-share agreements. But is all money created equal if you are on route to becoming a billion-dollar business? Dr. Astrid Scholz, the co-founder of Zebras Unite; Sydney Thomas, a principal at Precursor Ventures; and Brian Brackeen, the founding partner of Lightship Capital, joined us at TC Sessions: Justice to discuss alternative pathways to funding, and if the democratization of capital is a fa\u00e7ade.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<h3><strong>On the choice to stay away from traditional venture capital<\/strong><\/h3>\n<p>Scholz is currently building out Zebras Unite, a founder-led cooperative that is focused on making startups more sustainable, ethical and inclusive. During the panel, she mentioned that the capital arm of Zebras Unite could have been a traditional fund, but the organization ultimately decided to pursue more creative alternatives, such as the <a href=\"https:\/\/zebrasunite.coop\/capital-services\">Future Economy Lab<\/a>. This lab, which focuses on helping founders find financing instruments that fit their sectors, took place in Montreal with a focus on climate tech.<\/p>\n<p>Scholz shared why she went this route, versus a traditional fund:<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<blockquote><p>In the big scheme of things, [VC] really is just a tiny drop in the large capital pool of capital that&#8217;s out there. And then on the other extreme, you have bank loans. That may or may not be accessible to startup founders, especially if they&#8217;re from certain demographics in this country. Of course we have a massive racial wealth gap and access to capital.<\/p>\n<p>To me, that sounds just like two flavors of capital: vanilla and chocolate. It&#8217;s not interesting, if that was an ice cream store, it was not interesting. At Zebras Unite, we&#8217;re looking to increase the diversity of capital, as well as the diversity of managers of capital. So we&#8217;re very interested in revenue-based financing mechanisms. We&#8217;re very interested in non-dilutive early-stage forms of support to entrepreneurs who don&#8217;t have friends and family wealth. We were looking at new sorts of character-based lending instruments and a bunch of blended approaches, so there&#8217;s more room on the capital spectrum to color in, beyond the two ends of the spectrum. <em><strong>(Timestamp: 3:52)<\/strong><\/em><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<ul>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/04\/sec-loosens-crowdfunding-regs-so-small-businesses-can-raise-alternative-financing-in-pandemic\/\">SEC loosens crowdfunding regs so small businesses can raise alternative financing in pandemic<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/09\/08\/angellist-pioneers-rolling-vc-funds-in-pivot-to-saas\/\">AngelList pioneers rolling VC funds in pivot to SaaS<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/08\/19\/who-are-the-major-revenue-based-investing-vcs\/\">Who are the major revenue-based investing VCs?<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/26\/how-to-approach-and-work-with-the-3-types-of-corporate-vcs\/\">How to approach (and work with) the 3 types of corporate VCs<\/a><\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<hr \/>\n<h3><strong>On why venture capital paths can be formed around a more inclusive strategy<\/strong><\/h3>\n<p>Now, venture capital isn\u2019t the devil, and in a market as hot as right now it\u2019s clear that there is a huge demand to back great ideas. The problem starts when you look at which ideas get backed versus which don\u2019t, and underrepresented founders lose out at a disproportionately higher rate than white founders.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"O9udKYybo4\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/07\/07\/8-black-investors-discuss-the-intersection-of-race-tech-and-vc\/\">8 Black investors discuss the intersection of race, tech and funding<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;8 Black investors discuss the intersection of race, tech and funding&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/07\/07\/8-black-investors-discuss-the-intersection-of-race-tech-and-vc\/embed\/#?secret=O9udKYybo4\" data-secret=\"O9udKYybo4\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>Standards help everyone get on the same page, and in venture, any clarity around how one investor cuts checks versus another can help curb signaling risk and help set expectations on early-stage founders. Lightship Capital uses traditional venture capital but applies it in a way Brackeen thinks is more inclusive to founders.<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>Oftentimes, VCs talk about designing your product for your customer, but then they don&#8217;t design themselves around the customer. They completely ignore what they tell people to do. And so we&#8217;re designed for the underrepresented founders. And for us, that&#8217;s women, minorities, LGBTQ, plus disabled. And so the capital path for that founder is different from the white-male Zuckerberg founder. Oftentimes, a Series A is very, very difficult, so we bridge that. We\u2019ll write a smaller check &#8212; half a million dollars first &#8212; and then we\u2019ll reserve $1.5 million so they can go out and get a Series A done. And so to do that, we don&#8217;t require board seats and things of that nature, we do require strong collaboration<em>. <strong>(Timestamp: 7:03)<\/strong><\/em><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<ul>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/06\/revenue-based-financing-the-next-step-for-private-equity-and-early-stage-investment\/\">Flexible VC: A new model for startups targeting profitability<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/10\/10\/venture-capital-gets-less-diverse-in-2020\/\">Venture capital gets less diverse in 2020<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/06\/09\/if-youre-not-investing-in-diverse-founders-youre-a-bad-investor\/\">If you\u2019re not investing in diverse founders, you\u2019re a bad investor<\/a><\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<hr \/>\n<h3><strong>On how your first check could impact your next check <\/strong><\/h3>\n<p>Thomas noted that Indie.vc, an alternative financing program that was aimed at slow-growth, bootstrapped founders, shutting down this past week could be a lesson for founders who look to finance their companies from the plethora of programs out there.<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>They were at the frontiers of building access to new capital. I think one of the things that we saw when we would talk to founders who were considering Indie.vc capital versus our capital was, \u2018does the investor that you would like after you get that Indie.vc funding, if you decide to go to a more traditional VC firm? Can they actually even do revenue based financing investments, some people actually legitimately can&#8217;t because of the regulatory limits of their fund.<em><strong>(Timestamp: 16:28)<\/strong><\/em><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>She went on to explain how this isn\u2019t simply a one-off problem that could happen with. Precursor founding partner Charles Hudson penned a post, months ago, about the <a href=\"https:\/\/www.charleshudson.net\/we-only-have-100-points-of-equity-to-split-up\">messiness in early-stage cap tables. <\/a><\/p>\n<blockquote><p>I don&#8217;t want to say it&#8217;s unfair, but you have to make a pretty final decision, pretty early on in what type of company you want to build. And I don&#8217;t think that allows for a lot of the flexibility that is the reality of building a startup. When you pivot like five to 10 to 20 to 30 times before you finally get to something that, you know, matters. And so how do we also allow for more flexibility between multiple different types of revenue structures? I just don\u2019t think that exists right now. <strong>(Timestamp: 17:12) <\/strong><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<ul>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/07\/10\/a-recapitalization-reckoning\/\">A recapitalization reckoning<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/11\/23\/founders-seeking-their-first-check-need-a-fundraising-sales-funnel\/\">Founders seeking their first check need a fundraising sales funnel<\/a><\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<p>Brackeen added that his form loves non-dilutive financing before, and after, they are nicest. Pitch competitions might help a startup launch, but it won\u2019t help founders get from stage to stage. This banter basically answers the question that I set early on: is all capital created equal in the eyes of investors? A cap table filled with different types of financing structures and notes, as Thomas mentions, could lead to your next check investor declining to invest based on a semantic versus a lack of believing in your vision. One side effect we see here is <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/07\/10\/a-recapitalization-reckoning\/\">recapitalizations<\/a>, an event where startups restructure their entire cap table to squeeze out old investors, bring on new ones and shift the way equity and debt is managed.<\/p>\n<p>Scholz chimed in about how startups should think about capital limitations, but also other corporate structures that could shape the trajectory of a startup.<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>I think that point about founders basically getting locked into a corporate structure and an investment strategy before they even really know what they&#8217;re building or how it&#8217;s selling is just so important. I always joke, you know, like 99 out of 100 corporate lawyers will tell you to incorporate as a Delaware C. [But] that may or may not be the right answer. There may be a good reason to become a cooperative, and incorporating as a Delaware C will make your life very difficult.<strong> (Timestamp: 17:46)<\/strong><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<ul>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2016\/10\/02\/should-your-startup-take-the-b-corp-route\/\">Should your startup take the public benefit or B corp route?<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/03\/08\/which-types-of-startups-are-most-often-profitable\/\">Which types of startups are most often profitable?<\/a><\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<hr \/>\n<h3><strong>On if VC will be even more relevant five years from now<\/strong><\/h3>\n<p>The conversation turned into a broader discussion on if venture capital will be as relevant five years from now as it is today. While Scholz said that she doesn\u2019t even think venture is that important today, the two venture capitalists on the panel &#8212; Brackeen and Thomas &#8212; were good sports about the future of the asset class on which they have bet their careers.<\/p>\n<blockquote><p><strong>Thomas:<\/strong> The IPOs just keep on coming, and they keep getting bigger. It\u2019s crazy. I think that there is recreating an immense amount of wealth, and that we need to be thoughtful, we need to be careful. And we need to be just considerate of that fact. And so I plan to be in venture for the next 10 years. But I I think, to Astrid\u2019s point, we are not the only ones on the island. We are connected to all of these other different capital structures, and different communities. But my bet is still here. <strong>(Timestamp 25:14) <\/strong><\/p>\n<p><strong>Brackeen:<\/strong> Capital will continue to play a large role in capitalism, because the two are hand in hand. And venture capital is a version of that. Watch what we do. To see billions of dollars go into these geographies, these communities, these groups, the value creation is outrageous. Morgan Stanley, and others say that racism and sexism cost this country somewhere between $4 trillion and $16 trillion in kind of untapped value. So venture capital can be a key lever in opening that faucet. <strong>(Timestamp: 25:52)<\/strong><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<ul>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/03\/venture-capital-is-going-to-get-even-bigger-faster-and-more-expensive-this-year\/\">Venture capital is going to get even bigger, faster and more expensive this year<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/01\/21\/lame-lps-founder-referenceability-and-the-future-of-vc-signaling\/\"> Lame LPs, founder referenceability and the future of VC signaling<\/a><\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<p><span class=\"embed-youtube embed breakout embed--video\" style=\"text-align:center; display: block;\"><iframe class='youtube-player' width='640' height='360' src='https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/embed\/XXgr2a_su4s?version=3&#038;rel=1&#038;showsearch=0&#038;showinfo=1&#038;iv_load_policy=1&#038;fs=1&#038;hl=en-US&#038;autohide=2&#038;wmode=transparent' allowfullscreen='true' style='border:0;' sandbox='allow-scripts allow-same-origin allow-popups allow-presentation'><\/iframe><\/span><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/otter.ai\/u\/NwS2G1_Oe5NvNKaQvpEnccKVNy8\">You can read the entire transcript here.<\/a><\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p><em><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/26\/techcrunch-early-stage-is-the-startup-bootcamp-youve-always-needed\/?tpcc=ECTW2020\">Early Stage<\/a> is the premier &#8220;how-to&#8221; event for startup entrepreneurs and investors. You\u2019ll hear firsthand how some of the most successful founders and VCs build their businesses, raise money and manage their portfolios. We\u2019ll cover every aspect of company building: Fundraising, recruiting, sales, product-market fit, PR, marketing and brand building. Each session also has audience participation built-in &#8212; there\u2019s ample time included for audience questions and discussion.<\/em><\/p>\n<p>\t<iframe\n\t\t\tid=\"wpcom-iframe-dde292b93a5f3017145419dd51bb9fce\"\n\t\t\twidth=\"99%\"\n\t\t\theight=\"1500\"\n\t\t\tsrc=\"https:\/\/tcprotectedembed.com\/protected-iframe\/dde292b93a5f3017145419dd51bb9fce\"\n\t\t\tscrolling=\"true\"\n\t\t\tframeborder=\"0\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"wpcom-protected-iframe\"\n\t>\n\t<\/iframe>\n\t<script [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574362,"featured_media":2107225,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"outcome":"","status":"","crunchbase_tag":0,"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"1155aa06-92f5-3e4a-a171-06f2af27b1f2"},"categories":[17396,35394854],"tags":[576851086,576608144,576860863,576822285,576594983],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[576821871],"jetpack_featured_media_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/02\/justice-speaker-brackeen-thomas-scholz.jpg","shortlink":"https:\/\/tcrn.ch\/3kXr5mD","rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"premiumContent":false,"premiumCutoffPercent":1,"featured":false,"subtitle":"","seoTitle":"","seoDescription":"","tc_cb_mapping":[],"associatedEvent":{"ad":{"display":true,"title":"Join 2021","termID":576821871},"event":2067158,"authors":[133574362],"hide_featured_image":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2121723"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/types\/post"}],"replies":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/comments?post=2121723"}],"version-history":[{"count":0,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2121723\/revisions"}],"authors":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/133574362"}],"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/edit":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-admin\/post.php?post=2121723&action=edit"}],"author":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/133574362"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/media\/2107225"}],"wp:attachment":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/media?parent=2121723"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories?post=2121723"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags?post=2121723"},{"taxonomy":"_tc_cb_tag_taxonomy","embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/crunchbase_tag?post=2121723"},{"taxonomy":"tc_stories_tax","embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_stories_tax?post=2121723"},{"taxonomy":"tc_ec_category","embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category?post=2121723"},{"taxonomy":"tc_event","embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event?post=2121723"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]},"_embedded":{"authors":[{"id":133574362,"name":"Natasha Mascarenhas","url":"","description":"","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/author\/natasha-mascarenhas\/","slug":"natasha-mascarenhas","avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\/\/secure.gravatar.com\/avatar\/2f10add080685bb138750d850afec5b4?s=24&d=identicon&r=g","48":"https:\/\/secure.gravatar.com\/avatar\/2f10add080685bb138750d850afec5b4?s=48&d=identicon&r=g","96":"https:\/\/secure.gravatar.com\/avatar\/2f10add080685bb138750d850afec5b4?s=96&d=identicon&r=g"},"links":{"twitter":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/nmasc_","crunchbase":"https:\/\/www.crunchbase.com\/person\/natasha-mascarenhas-734f"},"position":null,"cbDescription":"<p>Natasha Mascarenhas is a reporter at TechCrunch covering early stage startups and venture capital trends. She also tracks the different networks that play into founder success, from loneliness to immigration. Before TechCrunch, Natasha reported on the same beat for Crunchbase News. She also has bylines in the Boston Globe, The San Francisco Chronicle, BostInno, and is proudly from New Jersey.<\/p>\n\n<p>Reach Natasha via e-mail at natasha.m@techcrunch.com or through DM on Twitter @nmasc_.<\/p>","cbAvatar":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/01\/x9fberhwpqwxusvvlxfj.png.png","twitter":"nmasc_","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/133574362"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users"}]}}],"author":[{"id":133574362,"name":"Natasha Mascarenhas","url":"","description":"","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/author\/natasha-mascarenhas\/","slug":"natasha-mascarenhas","avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\/\/secure.gravatar.com\/avatar\/2f10add080685bb138750d850afec5b4?s=24&d=identicon&r=g","48":"https:\/\/secure.gravatar.com\/avatar\/2f10add080685bb138750d850afec5b4?s=48&d=identicon&r=g","96":"https:\/\/secure.gravatar.com\/avatar\/2f10add080685bb138750d850afec5b4?s=96&d=identicon&r=g"},"links":{"twitter":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/nmasc_","crunchbase":"https:\/\/www.crunchbase.com\/person\/natasha-mascarenhas-734f"},"position":null,"cbDescription":"<p>Natasha Mascarenhas is a reporter at TechCrunch covering early stage startups and venture capital trends. Cribs","url":"\/shows\/tc-cribs","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":1605180,"object":"custom","type":"custom","type_label":"Custom Link","children":[]}]},"entities":{"posts":[{"id":2122624,"date":"2021-03-08T15:20:32","date_gmt":"2021-03-08T23:20:32","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2122624"},"modified":"2021-03-08T15:20:32","modified_gmt":"2021-03-08T23:20:32","slug":"max-q-starships-good-landing-and-less-good-post-landing","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/max-q-starships-good-landing-and-less-good-post-landing\/","title":{"rendered":"Max Q: Starship&#8217;s good landing (and less good post-landing)"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><em>Max Q is a weekly newsletter from TechCrunch all about space. <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/newsletters\">Sign up here to receive it weekly on Mondays in your inbox<\/a>.<\/em><\/p>\n<p>Sometimes even the biggest successes look like failures on video. That&#8217;s the theme of this week, because the biggest news by far was SpaceX&#8217;s test launch of its latest Starship prototype in South Texas.<\/p>\n<h3>It looked fake \u2013\u00a0but the fireball proved it wasn&#8217;t<\/h3>\n<p>SpaceX&#8217;s test flight was a launch of the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/03\/spacexs-starship-prototype-flies-to-32000-feet-and-sticks-the-landing-in-third-flight-test\/\">10th Starship prototype to a height of around 32,000 feet<\/a>, at which point it used its Raptor engines to flip into a flop maneuver and then fall back to Earth in a roughly horizontal orientation, before re-lighting its engines very near the ground and flipping back vertical for a soft landing. All of which actually happened as described, for the first time, causing many TC readers to suggest it was an elaborate CG fake.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>It wasn&#8217;t \u2013 after SpaceX cameras cut away, but while others were luckily still filming, the SN10 prototype met the same fiery end as the last two SpaceX rockets to do the high-flying act. The explosion that totally destroyed the rocket happened a few minutes after it sat stationary post-landing, and while it maybe didn&#8217;t provide the best optics, the real takeaway is that SpaceX proved the crazy landing maneuver Starship will use for reusability actually works in real-world conditions.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2066317\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/10\/Starlink-UT.jpg\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2066317\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2066317\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/10\/Starlink-UT.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1024\" height=\"575\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/10\/Starlink-UT.jpg 1390w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/10\/Starlink-UT.jpg?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/10\/Starlink-UT.jpg?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/10\/Starlink-UT.jpg?resize=768,432 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/10\/Starlink-UT.jpg?resize=680,382 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/10\/Starlink-UT.jpg?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><\/a><p id=\"caption-attachment-2066317\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Starlink&#8217;s UT antenna for residential customers.<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>SpaceX kinda needs the Starship to start working more and more often, because the big new rocket has a lot of work to do. As the space company continues to launch its <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/04\/spacex-launches-60-new-starlink-satellites-while-starship-moves-closer-to-being-able-to-launch-up-to-400-at-a-time\/\">Starlink satellites, including 60 more this past week<\/a>, it really wants to be launching up to 400 at a time using Starship&#8217;s generous cargo compartment. And there are humans waiting in the wings for a Starship ride, too: Japanese billionaire Yusaku Maezawa, who bought out an entire Starship mission for a trip around the Moon and back in 2023 has <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/02\/spacexs-first-paying-moon-flight-customer-wants-to-give-away-eight-seats-aboard-his-spaceship\/\">opened applications for 8 other passengers who will join him \u2013 at his expense<\/a>.<\/p>\n<h3>The SPAC man closes out his personal stake<\/h3>\n<p>Chamath Palihapitiya, the Chairman of Virgin Galactic, has <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/05\/virgin-galactic-chairman-chamath-palihapitiya-sells-off-remaining-personal-stake-in-the-space-company\/\">sold his entire personal stake in the company<\/a> after ushering it into the public markets last year via a SPAC merger with his Social Capital Hedosophia. Palihapitiya still retains a 6.2% ownership stake via that vehicle, in partnership with Ian Osborne, but his own independent holdings are now at zero.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2121532\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/10573763856_959b93767d_k.jpg\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2121532\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2121532\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/10573763856_959b93767d_k.jpg\" alt=\"Chamath Palihapitiya\" width=\"1024\" height=\"680\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/10573763856_959b93767d_k.jpg 1920w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/10573763856_959b93767d_k.jpg?resize=150,100 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/10573763856_959b93767d_k.jpg?resize=300,199 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/10573763856_959b93767d_k.jpg?resize=768,510 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/10573763856_959b93767d_k.jpg?resize=680,452 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/10573763856_959b93767d_k.jpg?resize=1536,1020 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/10573763856_959b93767d_k.jpg?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><\/a><p id=\"caption-attachment-2121532\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> TechCrunch<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Palihapitiya says he &#8220;remains as dedicated as ever to Virgin Galactic&#8217;s team, mission and prospects,&#8221; and that the only reason he liquidated his position was to provide funds for a climate-focused investment he&#8217;ll be taking the lid off soon. Public market investors seem not to have retained the same confidence, however, with price down consistently since news of the Chairman&#8217;s sale came out last week.<\/p>\n<h3>Early Stage<\/h3>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/26\/techcrunch-early-stage-is-the-startup-bootcamp-youve-always-needed\/?tpcc=ECTW2020\">Early Stage<\/a> is the premier \u201chow-to\u201d event for startup entrepreneurs and investors. You\u2019ll hear firsthand how some of the most successful founders and VCs build their businesses, raise money and manage their portfolios. We\u2019ll cover every aspect of company building: Fundraising, recruiting, sales, product-market fit, PR, marketing and brand building. Each session also has audience participation built-in \u2014 there\u2019s ample time included for audience questions and discussion.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"tzkDVJ5RPz\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/12\/29\/as-launch-market-matures-space-opportunities-on-the-ground-take-off\/\">As launch market matures, space opportunities on the ground take off<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;As launch market matures, space opportunities on the ground take off&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/12\/29\/as-launch-market-matures-space-opportunities-on-the-ground-take-off\/embed\/#?secret=tzkDVJ5RPz\" data-secret=\"tzkDVJ5RPz\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Max Q is a weekly newsletter from TechCrunch all about space. Crunch: PayPal acquires Curv"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">PayPal acquires a cryptocurrency startup, Apple discontinues the iMac Pro and McAfee sells its enterprise business. This is your Daily Crunch for March 8, 2021.<\/p>\n<p><strong>The big story: PayPal acquires Curv<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>This deal will grow PayPal&#8217;s cryptocurrency team by <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/paypal-to-acquire-cryptocurrency-custody-startup-curv\/\">bringing on Curv<\/a>, a startup working with exchanges, brokers and over-the-counter desks to help their users store crypto assets securely and access their wallets without requiring additional hardware.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>The larger company already supports the buying and selling of cryptocurrencies, and it says it plans to launch new crypto-related products in other countries and in Venmo.\u00a0Calcalist was the first to <a href=\"https:\/\/www.calcalist.co.il\/internet\/articles\/0,7340,L-3896291,00.html\">report the acquisition<\/a>, and it said that the deal price was between $200 and $300 million, while another source tells TechCrunch that the price was less than $200 million.<\/p>\n<p><strong>The tech giants<\/strong><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/07\/the-imac-pro-is-being-discontinued\/\">The iMac Pro is being discontinued<\/a> \u2014\u00a0Apple will stop selling the all-in-one once the current stock is depleted.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/mcafee-sells-enterprise-biz-to-symphony-technology-group-for-4b\/\">McAfee sells enterprise biz to Symphony Technology Group for $4B<\/a> \u2014\u00a0McAfee President and Chief Executive Officer Peter Leav said the company has decided to direct its resources to the consumer side of the business.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/07\/google-unveils-25-million-in-grants-aimed-at-empowering-women-and-girls\/\">Google unveils $25M in grants aimed at empowering women and girls<\/a> \u2014 Google.org\u2019s new Impact Challenge, unveiled on International Women\u2019s Day, is aimed at addressing systemic barriers and inequities.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Startups, funding and venture capital<\/strong><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/uk-challenger-bank-starling-raises-376m-now-valued-at-1-9b\/\">UK challenger bank Starling raises $376M, now valued at $1.9B<\/a> \u2014 Starling,\u00a0which competes against incumbent banks, as well as other challengers like Monzo and Revolut, says it&#8217;s already profitable.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/cosi-raises-e20m\/\">Cosi raises \u20ac20M for its \u2018full-stack\u2019 approach to short-term rentals<\/a> \u2014 The company signs long-term leases with property owners, then furnishes those apartments itself to \u201ccontrol\u201d the interior design experience.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/swiss-maker-of-meat-alternatives-planted-will-expand-and-diversify-with-18m-series-a\/\">Swiss maker of meat alternatives Planted will expand and diversify with $18M Series A<\/a> \u2014\u00a0With new kebabs and pulled-style faux meats available and steak-like cuts in the (literal) pipeline, Planted has begun to set its sights outside central Europe.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Advice and analysis from Extra Crunch<\/strong><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/from-electric-charging-to-supply-chain-management-inmotion-ventures-preps-jaguar-for-a-sustainable-future\/\">From electric charging to supply chain management, InMotion Ventures preps Jaguar for a sustainable future<\/a> \u2014\u00a0A look at InMotion Ventures, the independent investment and incubation initiative set up by Jaguar Land Rover.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/olos-ipo-could-value-the-company-north-of-3b-as-toast-waits-in-the-wings\/\">Olo\u2019s IPO could value the company north of $3B as Toast waits in the wings<\/a> \u2014\u00a0Olo, the New York-based fintech startup that provides order processing software to restaurants, shared its initial IPO price range this morning.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/white-label-voice-assistants-will-win-the-battle-for-podcast-discovery\/\">White-label voice assistants will win the battle for podcast discovery<\/a> \u2014 Listeners have never had so many choices for smart and compelling podcast content, with new exciting shows emerging daily.<\/p>\n<p>(Extra Crunch is our membership program, which helps founders and startup teams get ahead. <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/subscribe\/\">You can sign up here<\/a>.)<\/p>\n<p><strong>Everything else<\/strong><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/announcing-the-agenda-for-tc-early-stage-operations-fundraising\/\">Announcing the agenda for TC Early Stage \u2014 Operations &amp; Fundraising<\/a> \u2014\u00a0You\u2019ve got questions. TechCrunch Early Stage will have answers for you on April 1 and 2.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/a-glimpse-inside-the-minds-of-techs-dei-leaders\/\">A glimpse inside the minds of tech\u2019s DEI leaders<\/a> \u2014 We spoke with Uber Chief Diversity Officer Bo Young Lee and Netflix VP of Inclusion Strategy for Product Wade Davis about the work that still needs to be done.<\/p>\n<p><em>The Daily Crunch is TechCrunch&#8217;s roundup of our biggest and most important stories.
