\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=37313"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=37313"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=37313"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=37313"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":3374,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/kids\/","name":"kids","slug":"kids","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/3374"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=3374"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=3374"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=3374"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=3374"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":1053,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/parents\/","name":"parents","slug":"parents","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/1053"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=1053"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=1053"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=1053"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=1053"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":2060,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/podcasts\/","name":"podcasts","slug":"podcasts","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/2060"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=2060"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=2060"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=2060"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=2060"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":45141,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/streaming\/","name":"streaming","slug":"streaming","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/45141"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=45141"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=45141"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=45141"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=45141"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":518,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/trends\/","name":"trends","slug":"trends","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/518"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=518"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=518"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=518"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=518"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2121515,"date":"2021-03-08T09:29:53","date_gmt":"2021-03-08T17:29:53","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2121515"},"modified":"2021-03-08T14:17:47","modified_gmt":"2021-03-08T22:17:47","slug":"europes-android-choice-screen-keeps-burying-better-options","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/europes-android-choice-screen-keeps-burying-better-options\/","title":{"rendered":"Europe&#8217;s Android &#8216;choice&#8217; screen keeps burying better options"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">It&#8217;s been over a year since Google begun <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/08\/02\/google-to-auction-slots-on-android-default-search-choice-screen-in-europe-next-year-rivals-cry-pay-to-play-foul\/\">auctioning slots<\/a> for a search engine &#8216;choice&#8217; screen on Android in Europe, following a major antitrust intervention by the European Commission back in 2018. But despite hitting Google with a record-breaking fine over two years ago almost nothing has changed.<\/p>\n<p>The tech giant&#8217;s search marketshare remains undented and the most interesting regional search alternatives are being priced out of a Google-devised &#8216;remedy&#8217; that favors those who can pay the most to be listed as an alternative to its own dominant search engine on smartphones running Google&#8217;s Android OS.<\/p>\n<p>Quarterly choice screen winners have been getting increasingly same-y. Alternatives to Google are expecting another uninspiring batch of &#8216;winners&#8217; to drop in short order.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>The <a href=\"https:\/\/www.android.com\/choicescreen-winners\/\">results for Q1 2021<\/a> were dominated by a bunch of ad-targeting search options few smartphone users would likely have heard of: Germany&#8217;s GMX; California-based info.com; and Puerto Rico-based PrivacyWall (which is owned by a company whose <a href=\"https:\/\/socialgamemedia.com\/#services\">website<\/a> is emblazoned with the slogan &#8220;100% programmatic advertising&#8221;) &#8212; plus another, more familiar (ad)tech giant&#8217;s search engine (Microsoft-owned) Bing.<\/p>\n<p>Lower down the list: The Russian &#8216;Google&#8217; &#8212; Yandex &#8212; which won eight slots. And a veteran player in the Czech search market, Seznam.cz, which bagged two.<\/p>\n<p>On the &#8216;big loser&#8217; side: Non-tracking search engine, DuckDuckGo &#8212; which has been standing up for online privacy for over a decade yet won only one slot (in Belgium). It&#8217;s been come to be almost entirely squeezed out vs<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/01\/10\/duckduckgo-still-critical-of-googles-eu-android-choice-screen-auction-after-wining-a-universal-slot\/\">\u00a0winning a universal slot in all markets<\/a> at the start of the auction process.<\/p>\n<p>Tree-planting not-for-profit search engine, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.ecosia.org\/?c=en\">Ecosia<\/a>, was almost entirely absent in the last round too: Gaining only one slot on the screen showed to Android users in Slovenia. Yet back in December Ecosia was added as a default search option with Safari on iOS, iPadOS and macOS &#8212; having grown its global usage to more than 15 million users.<\/p>\n<p>While another homegrown European search option &#8212; which has a privacy-focus &#8212; France&#8217;s Qwant, went home with just one slot. And not in its home market, either (in tiny Luxembourg).<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"ywqLGhTRZN\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/10\/27\/googles-eu-android-choice-screen-isnt-working-say-search-rivals-calling-for-a-joint-process-to-devise-a-fair-remedy\/\">Google&#8217;s EU Android choice screen isn&#8217;t working say search rivals, calling for a joint process to devise a fair remedy<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Google&#8217;s EU Android choice screen isn&#8217;t working say search rivals, calling for a joint process to devise a fair remedy&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/10\/27\/googles-eu-android-choice-screen-isnt-working-say-search-rivals-calling-for-a-joint-process-to-devise-a-fair-remedy\/embed\/#?secret=ywqLGhTRZN\" data-secret=\"ywqLGhTRZN\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>If Europe&#8217;s regulators had fondly imagined that a Google-devised &#8216;remedy&#8217; for major antitrust breaches they identified would automagically restore thriving competition to the Android search market they should feel rudely awakened indeed. The bald fact is Google&#8217;s marketshare has not even been scratched, let alone dented.<\/p>\n<p>Statista data for Google&#8217;s search market share on mobile (across both Android and iOS; the latter where the tech giant pays Apple billions of dollars annually to be set as the default on iPhones) shows that in February 2021 its share in Europe stood at 97.07% &#8212; up from 96.92% in July 2018 when the Commission made the antitrust ruling.<\/p>\n<p>Yes, Google has actually <em>gained<\/em> share running this &#8216;remedy&#8217;.<\/p>\n<p>By any measure that&#8217;s a spectacular failure for EU competition enforcement &#8212; more than 2.5 years after its headline grabbing antitrust decision against Android.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"9e2GUNi1yk\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/07\/18\/google-gets-slapped-5bn-by-eu-for-android-antitrust-abuse\/\">Google gets slapped with $5BN EU fine for Android antitrust abuse<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Google gets slapped with $5BN EU fine for Android antitrust abuse&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/07\/18\/google-gets-slapped-5bn-by-eu-for-android-antitrust-abuse\/embed\/#?secret=9e2GUNi1yk\" data-secret=\"9e2GUNi1yk\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>The Commission has also been promoting a goal of European tech sovereignty throughout the period Google has been running this auction. President Ursula von der Leyen links this overrarching goal to her digital policy programming.<\/p>\n<p>On the measure of tech sovereignty the Android choice screen must be seen as a sizeable failure too &#8212; as it&#8217;s not only failed to support (most) homegrown alternatives to Google (another, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/01\/cliqz-pulls-the-plug-on-a-european-anti-tracking-alternative-to-google-search\/\">Cliqz, pulled the plug on its search+browser effort entirely last year<\/a>, putting part of the blame on the region&#8217;s political stakeholders for failing to understand the need for Europe to own its own digital infrastructure) &#8212; but it&#8217;s actively burying the most interesting European alternatives by forcing them to compete against a bunch of ad-funded Google clones.<\/p>\n<p>(And if Brave Search takes off it&#8217;ll be another non-European alternative &#8212; albeit, one that will have benefitted from expertise and tech that was made-in-Europe&#8230; )<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"E4nLE3s8bh\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/03\/brave-is-launching-its-own-search-engine-with-the-help-of-ex-cliqz-devs-and-tech\/\">Brave is launching its own search engine with the help of ex-Cliqz devs and tech<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Brave is launching its own search engine with the help of ex-Cliqz devs and tech&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/03\/brave-is-launching-its-own-search-engine-with-the-help-of-ex-cliqz-devs-and-tech\/embed\/#?secret=E4nLE3s8bh\" data-secret=\"E4nLE3s8bh\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>This is because the auction mechanism means only companies that pay Google the most can buy themselves a chance at being set as a default option on Android.<\/p>\n<p>Even in the rare instances where European players shell out enough money to appear in the choice list (which likely means they&#8217;ll be losing money per search click) they most often do so alongside other non-European alternatives <em>and Google<\/em> &#8212; further raising the competitive bar for selection.<\/p>\n<p>It doesn&#8217;t have to be this way. Nor was it wasn&#8217;t initially; Google started with a choice screen based on marketshare.<\/p>\n<p>However it very quickly switched to a pay to play model &#8212; throttling at a stroke the discoverability of alternative business models that aren&#8217;t based on exploiting user data (or, indeed, aren&#8217;t profit-driven in Ecosia&#8217;s case; as it uses ad-generated revenue to fund tree planting with a purely environmental goal).<\/p>\n<p>Such alternatives say they typically can&#8217;t afford to win Google&#8217;s choice screen auctions. (It&#8217;s worth noting that those who do participate in the game are restricted in what they can say as Google requires they sign an NDA.)<\/p>\n<p>Clearly, it&#8217;s no coincidence that the winners of Google&#8217;s auction skew almost entirely to the track and target side of the tracks, where its own business sits; all data-exploiting business models bandied together. And then, from a consumer point of view, why would you <em>not<\/em> pick Google with such a poorly and artificially limited &#8216;choice&#8217; on offer &#8212; since you&#8217;re generally only being offered weaker versions of the same thing?<\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">Ecosia tells TechCrunch it&#8217;s now considering pulling out of the auction process altogether &#8212; which would be a return to its first instinct; which was to boycott the auction before saying it felt it had to participate. <\/span><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">A few months playing Google&#8217;s pay-to-play &#8216;no choice&#8217; (as <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/07\/30\/googles-no-choice-screen-on-android-isnt-working-says-ecosia-querying-the-eus-approach-to-antitrust-enforcement\/\">Ecosia dubs the auction<\/a>) game has cemented its view that the system is stacked against genuine alternatives.\u00a0\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"M7jV0LDio6\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/07\/30\/googles-no-choice-screen-on-android-isnt-working-says-ecosia-querying-the-eus-approach-to-antitrust-enforcement\/\">Google&#8217;s &#8216;no choice&#8217; screen on Android isn&#8217;t working, says Ecosia &#8212; querying the EU&#8217;s approach to antitrust enforcement<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Google&#8217;s &#8216;no choice&#8217; screen on Android isn&#8217;t working, says Ecosia &#8212; querying the EU&#8217;s approach to antitrust enforcement&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/07\/30\/googles-no-choice-screen-on-android-isnt-working-says-ecosia-querying-the-eus-approach-to-antitrust-enforcement\/embed\/#?secret=M7jV0LDio6\" data-secret=\"M7jV0LDio6\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p><span class=\"il\">Over two auction rounds when Ecosia has only ended up winning the one slot each time it says it&#8217;s<\/span> seen no positive effect on user numbers. A decision on whether or not to withdraw entirely will be taken after the results of the next auction process are revealed, it said. (The next round of results are expected shortly, in early March.)<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;We definitely realized it&#8217;s less and less &#8216;fun&#8217; to play the game,&#8221; Ecosia founder Christian Kroll told us. &#8220;It&#8217;s a super unfair game &#8212; where it&#8217;s not only &#8216;David against Goliath&#8217; but also Goliath gets to choose the rules, gets a free ticket, he can change the rules of game if he likes to. So it&#8217;s not amusing for us to participate in that.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;We&#8217;ve been participating now for nine months and if you look at overall marketshare in Europe nothing has changed. We don&#8217;t know the results yet of this round but I assume also nothing will change &#8212; the usual suspects will be there again&#8230; Most of the options that you see there now are not interesting to users.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Calling it a &#8216;choice&#8217; screen is still a little bit ironic if you remove all the interesting choices from the screen. So the situation is still the same and it becomes less and less fun to play the game and at some point I think we might make the decision that we&#8217;re not going to be part of the game anymore,&#8221; he added.<\/p>\n<p>Other alternative search engines we spoke to are continuing to participate for now &#8212; but all were critical of Google&#8217;s &#8216;pay-to-play&#8217; model for the Android &#8216;choice screen&#8217;.<\/p>\n<p>DuckDuckGo founder, Gabriel Weinberg, told us: &#8220;We are bidding, but only to help further expose to the European Commission how flawed Google&#8217;s rigged process really is, in hopes they will help more actively take a role in reforming it into something that actually works for consumers. Due to our strict privacy policy, we expect to be eliminated, same as last time.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>He pointed to a <a href=\"https:\/\/spreadprivacy.com\/search-preference-menu-duckduckgo-elimination\/\">blog post<\/a> the company put out last fall, denouncing the &#8220;fundamentally flawed&#8221; auction model &#8212; and saying that &#8220;whole piece still stands&#8221;. In the blog post the company wrote that despite being profitable since 2014 &#8220;we <span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">have been priced out of this auction because we choose to not maximize our profits by exploiting our users&#8221;. <\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">&#8220;In practical terms, this means our commitment to privacy and a cleaner search experience translates into less money per search. This means we must bid less relative to other, profit-maximizing companies,&#8221; DuckDuckGo went on, adding: &#8220;<\/span>This EU antitrust remedy is only serving to further strengthen Google\u2019s dominance in mobile search by boxing out alternative search engines that consumers want to use and, for those search engines that remain, taking most of their profits from the preference menu.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;This auction format incentivizes bidders to bid what they can expect to profit per user selection. The long-term result is that the participating Google alternatives must give most of their preference menu profits to Google! Google\u2019s auction further incentivizes search engines to be worse on privacy, to increase ads, and to not donate to good causes, because, if they do those things, then they could afford to bid higher,&#8221; it also said then.<\/p>\n<p>France&#8217;s Qwant has been similarly critical and it told us it is &#8220;extremely dissatisfied&#8221; with the auction &#8212; calling for &#8220;urgent modification&#8221; and saying the 2018 Commissio decision should be fully respected &#8220;in text and in spirit&#8221;.<\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">&#8220;We are extremely dissatisfied with the auction system. We are asking for an urgent modification of the Choice Screen to allow consumers to find the search engine they want to use and not just the three choices that are only the ones that pay the most Google. We demand full respect for the 2018 decision, in text and in spirit,&#8221; said CEO Jean-Claude Ghinozzi.<\/span><\/p>\n<p>&#8220;We are reviewing all options and re-evaluating our decision on a quarterly basis. In any case, we want consumers to be able to freely choose the search engine they prefer, without being limited to the only three alternative choices sold by Google. Consumers&#8217; interests must always come first,&#8221; he added.<\/p>\n<p>Russia&#8217;s Yandex confirmed it has participated in the upcoming Q2 auction. But it was also critical of Google&#8217;s implementation, saying it falls short of offering a genuine &#8220;freedom of choice&#8221; to Android users.<\/p>\n<div>\n<div>\n<p dir=\"ltr\">&#8220;We aim to offer high-quality and convenient search engine around the world. We are confident that freedom to select a search engine will lead to greater market competition and motivate each player to improve services. We don\u2019t think that the current EU solution fully ensures freedom of choice for users, by only covering devices released from March 2020,&#8221; a Yandex spokeswoman said.<\/p>\n<p dir=\"ltr\">&#8220;There are currently very few such devices on the EU market in comparison with the total number of devices in users&#8217; hands. It is essential to provide the freedom of choice that is genuine and real. Competition among service providers ultimately benefits users who will receive a better product.&#8221;<\/p>\n<\/div>\n<\/div>\n<p>One newcomer to the search space &#8212; the anti-tracking browser Brave (which, as we mentioned above, just bought up some Cliqz assets to underpin the forthcoming launch of an-own brand Brave Search) &#8212; confirmed it will not be joining in at all.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Brave does not plan to participate in this auction. Brave is about putting the user first, and this bidding process ignores users&#8217; best interests by limiting their choices and selecting only for highest Google Play Store optimizing bidders,&#8221; a spokeswoman said.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;An irony here is that Google gets to profit off its own remedy for being found guilty of anti-competitive tying of Chrome into Android,&#8221; she added.<\/p>\n<p>Asked about its strategy to grow usage of Brave Search in the region &#8212; outside of participation in the Android choice screen &#8212; she said: &#8220;Brave already has localized browsers for the European market, and we will continue to grow by offering best-in-class privacy showcased in marketing campaigns and referrals programs.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Google&#8217;s self-devised &#8216;remedy&#8217; followed a <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/07\/18\/google-gets-slapped-5bn-by-eu-for-android-antitrust-abuse\/\">2018 antitrust decision by the Commission<\/a> &#8212; which led to a record-breaking $5BN penalty and an order to cease a variety of infringing behaviors. The tech giant&#8217;s implementation remains under active monitoring by EU antitrust regulators. However Kroll argues the Commission is essentially just letting Google buy time rather than fix the abusive behavior it identified.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;The way I see this at the moment is the Commission feels like the auction screen isn&#8217;t necessarily something that they&#8217;ve requested as a remedy so they can&#8217;t really force Google to change it &#8212; and that&#8217;s why they also maybe don&#8217;t see it as their responsibility,&#8221; he said. &#8220;But at the same time they requested Google to solve the situation and Google isn&#8217;t doing anything.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;I think they are also allowing Google to get the credit from the press and also from users that it seems like Google is doing something &#8212; so they are allowing Google to play on time&#8230; I don&#8217;t know if a real choice screen would be a good solution but it&#8217;s also not for me to decide &#8212; it&#8217;s up to the European Commission to decide if Google has successfully remedied the damage&#8230; and has also compensated some of the damage that it&#8217;s done and I think that has not happened at all. We can see that in the [marketshare] numbers that basically still the same situation is happening.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;The whole thing is designed to remove interesting options from the screen,&#8221; he also argued of Google&#8217;s current &#8216;remedy&#8217;. &#8220;This is how it&#8217;s &#8216;working&#8217; and I&#8217;m of course disappointed that nobody is stepping in there. So we&#8217;re basically in this unfair game where we get beaten up by our competitors. And I would hope for some regulator to step in and say this is not how this should go. But this isn&#8217;t happening.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;At the moment our only choice is to hang in there but at the moment if we really see there is no effect and there&#8217;s also no chance that regulators will ever step in we still have the choice to completely withdraw and let Google have its fun but without us&#8230; We&#8217;re not only not getting anything out of the [current auction model] but we&#8217;re of course also investing into it. And there are also restrictions because of the NDA we&#8217;ve signed &#8212; and even those restrictions are a little bit of a pain. So we have all the negative effects and don&#8217;t get any benefits.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>While limited by NDA in what he can discuss about the costs involved with participating in the auction, Kroll suggested the winners are doing so at a loss &#8212; pursuing reach at the expense of revenue.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;If you look at the bids from the last rounds I think with those bids it would be difficult for us to make money &#8212; and so potentially others have lost money. And that&#8217;s exactly also how this auction is designed, or how most auctions are designed, is that the winners often lose money&#8230; so you have this winner&#8217;s curse where people overbid,&#8221; he said.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;This hasn&#8217;t happened to us &#8212; also because we&#8217;re super careful &#8212; and in the last round we won this wonderful slot in Slovenia. Which is a beautiful country but again it has no impact on our revenues and we didn&#8217;t expect that to happen. It&#8217;s just for us to basically participate in the game but not risk our financial health,&#8221; he added.\u00a0&#8220;We know that our bids will likely not win so the financial risk [to Ecosia as it&#8217;s currently participating and mostly losing in the auction] is not that big but for the companies who actually win bids &#8212; for them it might be a different thing.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Kroll points out that the auction model has allowed Google to continue harvesting marketshare while weakening its competitors.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;There are quite a few companies who can afford to lose money in search because they just need to build up marketshare &#8212; and Google is basically harvesting all that and at the same time weakening its competitors,&#8221; he argued. &#8220;Because competitors need to spend on this. And one element that &#8212; at least in the beginning when the auction started &#8212; that I didn&#8217;t even see was also that if you&#8217;re a real search company&#8230; then you&#8217;re building up a brand, you&#8217;re building up a product, you&#8217;re making all these investments and you have real users &#8212; and if you have those then, if there was really a choice screen, people would naturally choose you. But in this auction screen model you&#8217;re basically paying for users that you would have anyway.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;So it&#8217;s really putting those kind of companies at a disadvantage: DuckDuckGo, us, all kinds of companies who have a &#8216;real USP&#8217;. Also Lilo, potentially even Qwant as well if you have a more nationalist approach to search, basically. So all of those companies are put at an even bigger disadvantage. And that&#8217;s &#8212; I think &#8212; unfair.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Since most winners of auction slots are, like Google, involved in surveillance capitalism &#8212; gathering data on search users to profit off of ad targeting &#8212; if anyone was banking on EU competition enforcement being able to act as a lever to crack open the dominant privacy-hostile business model of the web (and allow less abusive alternatives get a foot in the door) they must be sorely disappointed.<\/p>\n<p>Better alternatives &#8212; that do not track consumers for ads; or, in the case of Ecosia, are on an entirely non-profit mission &#8212; are clearly being squeezed out.<\/p>\n<p>The Commission can&#8217;t say it wasn&#8217;t warned: <span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">The moment the auction model was announced by Google <a style=\"background-color: #ffffff; font-size: 1.125rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\" href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/08\/02\/google-to-auction-slots-on-android-default-search-choice-screen-in-europe-next-year-rivals-cry-pay-to-play-foul\/\">rivals decried it<\/a> as flawed, rigged, unfair and unsustainable &#8212; warning it would put them at a <\/span>competitive disadvantage (exactly because they aren&#8217;t just cloning Google&#8217;s &#8216;track and target for ad profit model&#8217;).<\/p>\n<p>Nonetheless, the Commission has so far shown itself unwilling or unable to respond &#8212; despite making a big show of <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/12\/30\/understanding-europes-big-push-to-rewrite-the-digital-rulebook\/\">proposing major new rules for the largest platforms<\/a> which it says are needed to ensure they play fair. But that raises the question of why it&#8217;s not better-enforcing existing EU rules against tech giants like Google?<\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">When we raised criticism of Google&#8217;s Android choice screen auction model with the Commission<\/span><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\"> it sent us its standard set of talking points &#8212; <\/span><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">writing that: &#8220;<\/span><span lang=\"EN-IE\" style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">We have seen in the past that a choice screen can be an effective way to promote user choice&#8221;.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span lang=\"EN-IE\" style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">&#8220;The choice screen means that additional search providers are presented to users on start-up of every new Android device in every EEA country. So users can now choose their search provider of preference when setting up their newly purchased Android devices,&#8221; it also said, adding that it is <\/span><span lang=\"EN-IE\" style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">&#8220;committed to a full and effective implementation of the decision&#8221;.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span lang=\"EN-IE\" style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">&#8220;We are therefore monitoring closely the implementation of the choice screen mechanism,&#8221; it added &#8212; a standard line since Google begin its &#8216;compliance&#8217; with the 2018 EU decision.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p>In a slight development, the Commission did also confirm it has had discussions with Google about the choice screen mechanism &#8212; <span lang=\"EN-IE\">following what it described as &#8220;relevant feedback from the market&#8221;.\u00a0 <\/span><\/p>\n<p><span lang=\"EN-IE\">It said these discussions focused on &#8220;the presentation and mechanics of the choice screen and to the selection mechanism of rival search providers&#8221;.<\/span><\/p>\n<p>But with the clock ticking, and genuine alternatives to Google search being actively squeezed out of the market &#8212; leaving European consumers to be offered no meaningful choice to privacy-hostile search on Android &#8212; you do have to wonder what regulators are waiting for?<\/p>\n<p>A pattern of reluctance to challenge tech giants where it counts seems to be emerging from Margrethe Vestager&#8217;s tenure at the helm of the competition department (and also, since 2019, a key shaper of EU digital policy).<\/p>\n<p>Despite gaining a reputation for being willing to take on tech giants &#8212; and hitting Google (and others) with a number of headline-grabbing fines over the past five+ years &#8212; she cannot claim success in rebalancing the market for mobile search nor smartphone operating systems nor search ad brokering, in just the most recent Google cases.<\/p>\n<p>Nonetheless she was content to green light Google&#8217;s acquisition of wearable maker Fitbit <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/12\/17\/europe-clears-google-fitbit-with-a-ten-year-ban-on-using-health-data-for-ads\/\">at the end of last year<\/a> &#8212; despite a multitude of voices raised against allowing the tech giant to further entrench its dominance.<\/p>\n<p>On that she argued defensively that concessions secured from Google would be sufficient to address concerns (such as a promise extracted from Google not to\u00a0 use Fitbit data for ads for at least ten years).<\/p>\n<p>But, given her record on monitoring Google&#8217;s compliance with a whole flush of EU antitrust rulings, it&#8217;s hard to see why anyone other than Google should be confident in the Commission&#8217;s ability or willingness to enforce its own mandates against Google. Complaints against how Google operates, meanwhile, just <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/11\/12\/act-now-before-google-kills-us-135-strong-coalition-of-startups-warns-eu-antitrust-chief\/\">keep stacking up<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;I think they are listening,&#8221; says Kroll of the Commission. &#8220;But what I am missing is action.&#8221;<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"ywqLGhTRZN\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/10\/27\/googles-eu-android-choice-screen-isnt-working-say-search-rivals-calling-for-a-joint-process-to-devise-a-fair-remedy\/\">Google&#8217;s EU Android choice screen isn&#8217;t working say search rivals, calling for a joint process to devise a fair remedy<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Google&#8217;s EU Android choice screen isn&#8217;t working say search rivals, calling for a joint process to devise a fair remedy&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/10\/27\/googles-eu-android-choice-screen-isnt-working-say-search-rivals-calling-for-a-joint-process-to-devise-a-fair-remedy\/embed\/#?secret=ywqLGhTRZN\" data-secret=\"ywqLGhTRZN\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"rDgZDLHB6Q\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/08\/14\/travel-startups-cry-foul-over-what-googles-doing-with-their-data\/\">Travel startups cry foul over what Google&#8217;s doing with their data<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; Vestager","slug":"margrethe-vestager","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/1797383"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=1797383"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=1797383"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=1797383"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=1797383"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":3279,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/privacy\/","name":"privacy","slug":"privacy","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/3279"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=3279"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=3279"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=3279"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=3279"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2122231,"date":"2021-03-08T09:05:18","date_gmt":"2021-03-08T17:05:18","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2122231"},"modified":"2021-03-08T14:13:54","modified_gmt":"2021-03-08T22:13:54","slug":"while-eyeing-a-spac-swedish-autonomous-ev-company-einride-nears-75-million-in-new-funding","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/while-eyeing-a-spac-swedish-autonomous-ev-company-einride-nears-75-million-in-new-funding\/","title":{"rendered":"While eyeing a SPAC, Swedish autonomous EV company Einride nears $75 million in new funding"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Swedish autonomous electric vehicle startup <a class=\"c-link\" href=\"https:\/\/www.einride.tech\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https:\/\/www.einride.tech\/\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\">Einride<\/a> is aiming to continue the momentum sparked by partnerships with Oatly and Lidl by seeking additional capital, TechCrunch has learned.<span class=\"c-message__edited_label\" dir=\"ltr\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\" aria-describedby=\"sk-tooltip-1917\">\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p>Einride is seeking $75 million in new financing, while at the same time exploring the potential for a public listing through a special purpose acquisition company, according to people with knowledge of the company&#8217;s plans.<\/p>\n<p>SPACs, a mechanism in which a publicly traded shell company merges with a private business, have taken the U.S. capital markets by storm led, in part, by startups focused on the electrification of mobility.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Early successes of public listings for companies like Nikola (<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/12\/23\/nikolas-stock-crashes-after-announcing-cancelation-of-contract-with-republic-services-for-2500-garbage-trucks\/\">despite its dubious claims<\/a>) helped set the stage for the SPAC boom. Canoo, Fisker Inc, ChargePoint and Lordstown Motors are just a few of the U.S.-based EV companies that have gone public via a SPAC in the past year.<\/p>\n<p>Unlike some newly minted SPAC companies, Einride has some fundamentals. The company has already piloted its technology <a href=\"https:\/\/www.einride.tech\/press\/oatly-reduces-carbon-footprint-first-month-einride-electric-trucks\">through a partnership with Oatly<\/a>, the Swedish oat milk maker.<\/p>\n<p>Oatly began using Einride\u2019s electric trucks on its delivery routes from each of its Swedish production sites in October 2020. Thus far, the trucks have driven over 8,600 km electric and as a result have saved over 10,500 kg of CO2 compared to diesel, according to a statement from the companies.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cSustainability is at the core of everything we do, and we work hard to lower our emissions across the board. This includes our emissions for transports, which is why we are now shifting to electrical vehicles, which reduces our climate footprint by 87% on these routes,\u201d said Simon Broadbent, supply chain director at Oatly, in a statement at the time.<\/p>\n<p>The deal with Oatly was just the beginning. As the ink dried on that partnership, Einride quickly signed other marquee Swedish businesses including the food shipping and logistics company Lidl and the electronics manufacturer Electrolux.<\/p>\n<p>Big automakers have electric and autonomous plans of their own. Argo, a developer of self-driving technology, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/07\/30\/self-driving-startup-argo-ai-hits-7-5-billion-valuation\/\">is now worth $7.5 billion<\/a> thanks to an investment from Ford and the VW Group. And VW&#8217;s Traton Group is pushing low emission and electrification through a $2.2 billion investment <a href=\"https:\/\/www.bloomberg.com\/news\/articles\/2019-10-02\/traton-to-pour-2-2-billion-into-electric-trucks-software\">announced in 2019<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>Daimler, Paccar, and Volvo<a href=\"https:\/\/medium.datadriveninvestor.com\/18-companies-and-startups-that-are-leading-the-race-for-the-autonomous-trucks-4ba5a50e6dee\"> all have plans<\/a> as well.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"NngBcuMkwS\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/07\/30\/self-driving-startup-argo-ai-hits-7-5-billion-valuation\/\">Self-driving startup Argo AI hits $7.5 billion valuation<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Self-driving startup Argo AI hits $7.5 billion valuation&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/07\/30\/self-driving-startup-argo-ai-hits-7-5-billion-valuation\/embed\/#?secret=NngBcuMkwS\" data-secret=\"NngBcuMkwS\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>That&#8217;s just scratching the surface of the money that&#8217;s pouring in to autonomous, electrified transport. Of course, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.tesla.com\/semi\">Tesla is in the game with its own semi truck<\/a> and, in China, Plus AI, is automating a number of vehicles from Manbang, Suning and FAW Jiefang.<\/p>\n<p id=\"bc9a\" class=\"is it ez iu b fy iv iw ix gb iy iz ja jb jc jd je jf jg jh ji jj jk jl jm jn dm fw\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">All of this money is aiming to capture a portion of the market for autonomous, electrified vehicles that the consulting firm McKinsey estimated would save the trucking industry over $100 billion. It&#8217;s a potentially huge opportunity in the $260 billion U.S. trucking market alone. Worldwide, businesses spend about $1.2 trillion on trucking, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.mckinsey.com\/industries\/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure\/our-insights\/distraction-or-disruption-autonomous-trucks-gain-ground-in-us-logistics\">according to McKinsey<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">The benefits that would accrue to the industry are more than just financial. Trucking is a huge component of the greenhouse gas emissions that come from the transportation sector &#8212; which includes road, rail, air and marine transportation. In 2016, trucking and transport broadly contributed to roughly 24% of the world&#8217;s total greenhouse gas emissions &#8212; and that number has been steadily increasing.<\/p>\n<p>Any reduction in carbon emissions from the transport sector would be a huge step forward on the path toward a more environmentally sustainable future.<\/p>\n<p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">No wonder venture investors are falling all over each other to invest in these companies. Einride counts EQT Ventures and NordicNinja VC, a fund backed by Panasonic, Honda, Omron and the Japan Bank for International Cooperation, among its investors. Along with backing from Ericsson Ventures, Norrsken Foundation, Plum Alley Investments and Plug and Play Ventures the startup has raised $32 million to date.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"6I59t98aGq\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/from-electric-charging-to-supply-chain-management-inmotion-ventures-preps-jaguar-for-a-sustainable-future\/\">From electric charging to supply chain management, InMotion Ventures preps Jaguar for a sustainable future<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;From electric charging to supply chain management, InMotion Ventures preps Jaguar for a sustainable future&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/from-electric-charging-to-supply-chain-management-inmotion-ventures-preps-jaguar-for-a-sustainable-future\/embed\/#?secret=6I59t98aGq\" data-secret=\"6I59t98aGq\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"48JKVLWNtx\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/10\/10\/autonomous-trucking-startup-einride-eyes-u-s-market-with-25-million-in-new-funding\/\">Autonomous trucking startup Einride eyes US market with $25 million in new funding<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" }],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=449557096"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=449557096"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=449557096"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576602979,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/startups\/recent-funding\/","name":"Recent Funding","slug":"recent-funding","taxonomy":"category","parent":20429,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/576602979"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/20429"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=576602979"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=576602979"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=576602979"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":20429,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/startups\/","name":"Startups","slug":"startups","taxonomy":"category","parent":0,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/20429"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=20429"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=20429"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=20429"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":17396,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tc\/","name":"TC","slug":"tc","taxonomy":"category","parent":0,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/17396"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=17396"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":449560352,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/einride\/","name":"einride","slug":"einride","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449560352"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449560352"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449560352"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449560352"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449560352"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":197443,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/electric-vehicles\/","name":"electric vehicles","slug":"electric-vehicles","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/197443"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=197443"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=197443"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=197443"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=197443"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2122245,"date":"2021-03-08T08:28:03","date_gmt":"2021-03-08T16:28:03","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2122245"},"modified":"2021-03-08T12:39:28","modified_gmt":"2021-03-08T20:39:28","slug":"makers-of-kids-first-virtual-world-animal-jam-targets-gen-z-teens-with-fer-al-debut","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/makers-of-kids-first-virtual-world-animal-jam-targets-gen-z-teens-with-fer-al-debut\/","title":{"rendered":"Makers of &#8216;kid&#8217;s first virtual world&#8217; Animal Jam targets Gen Z teens with Fer.al debut"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Before kids graduate to the expansive virtual worlds in games like Roblox, Minecraft and Fortnite, they often get their start in online social gaming with a game like <a href=\"https:\/\/www.animaljam.com\/en\">Animal Jam<\/a>. Here, kids learn to personalize their avatar, explore a world, chat with other players and trade items in a safe environment with parental controls. Today, the company behind this popular title, WildWorks, is launching a new game, <a href=\"https:\/\/fer.al\/en\">Fer.al<\/a>, which builds on Animal Jam&#8217;s legacy while catering to a slightly older crowd of Gen Z teens.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;When we started talking about Fer.al, it was the idea of where do kids go when they age out of Animal Jam?,&#8221; explains Clark Stacey, co-founder and CEO of WildWorks. &#8220;Because there isn&#8217;t a transitional space between a completely walled garden like Animal Jam and \u2026 Instagram and the adult social networks and games that don&#8217;t have those same protections,&#8221; he continues.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;We knew we wanted to provide a place for these older kids to go where the walls are a little bit lower,&#8221; Stacey adds.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>The new game is meant to cater to older kids &#8212; meaning young teens ages 13 to around 18 &#8212; who are now choosing their own games, have their own email address and don&#8217;t need parental permission to play. The guardrails on chat also won&#8217;t be as high on Fer.al as on Animal Jam and will focus more on preventing bullying and abuse than blocking words. Players will also be able to connect their online social accounts to their game accounts in the future.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2122288\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2122288\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2122288\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Creature_Customize.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"383\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Creature_Customize.png 1920w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Creature_Customize.png?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Creature_Customize.png?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Creature_Customize.png?resize=768,432 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Creature_Customize.png?resize=680,383 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Creature_Customize.png?resize=1536,864 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Creature_Customize.png?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2122288\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> WildWorks<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>With <a href=\"https:\/\/fer.al\/en\">Fer.al<\/a>, WildWorks is introducing another animal-centered title, but this time it&#8217;s moving into the fantasy realm. Players choose between bipedal humanoid creatures based on folklore and myth including a Kitsune, Senri, Dragon, Jackelope, Werewolf, Kirin or a Shinigami, with more to come in time.<\/p>\n<p>The characters&#8217; style was inspired by Animal Jam fan art, Stacey says, where kids would create animal avatars that were sort of a mix between manga, Animal Jam&#8217;s style, and other, older animation styles.<\/p>\n<p>Like its predecessor, Fer.al players will also be able to personalize their character and change their appearance, design their personal space (this time, a &#8220;sanctuary&#8221; instead of a &#8220;den,&#8221;) discover a world where they can interact with other players, collect items and trade, and venture on quests. But the storyline has also evolved to reflect teens&#8217; interests, including their growing understanding of social media and the desire to grow an online fan base.<\/p>\n<p>The larger narrative involves a reality show where two warring queens, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.instagram.com\/aradiafellqueen\/?hl=en\">Aradia<\/a> and <a href=\"https:\/\/www.instagram.com\/delilahlichqueen\/?hl=en\">Delilah<\/a> &#8212; each with their own Instagram account, naturally &#8212; are angling for control. The company isn&#8217;t offering a lot of details as to how this narrative plays out in the long term, but it will involve weekly and monthly contests as the game ramps up, in addition to the everyday missions and quests that are undertaken to gain ingredients to create new clothes or a new &#8220;glamour&#8221; (a rendering effect that goes around your character.)<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2122287\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2122287\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2122287\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_Roleplaying.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"383\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_Roleplaying.png 1920w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_Roleplaying.png?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_Roleplaying.png?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_Roleplaying.png?resize=768,432 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_Roleplaying.png?resize=680,383 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_Roleplaying.png?resize=1536,864 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_Roleplaying.png?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2122287\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> WildWorks<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Much like Animal Jam &#8212; or even other virtual worlds like some Roblox games &#8212; players are meant to engage in cooperative gameplay to advance. There will be tasks you can&#8217;t complete on your own, meaning you&#8217;ll need to interact and chat. You will also be able to join factions, initially driven by the two queens, as the game advances.<\/p>\n<p>Another notable aspect to Fer.al is that it&#8217;s largely designed to cater to girl gamers.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;It&#8217;s certainly not intended to be to the exclusion of boys who are in this age range,&#8221; explains Stacey. &#8220;But we recognize the fact that, among the most engaged Animal Jam players, it&#8217;s about 80% girls. We&#8217;ve leaned into that pretty heavily in Animal Jam &#8212; we&#8217;re trying to feature a lot of female scientists and working with them on causes that promote girls in STEM. So we know a lot of the built-in audience is coming from that,&#8221; he says.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;And I think the need that we recognized is that it&#8217;s not hard for adolescent boys to find online communities that jive with them. It&#8217;s pretty hard for girls to find the same thing. So, as we&#8217;re creating this community &#8212; everything from the rules to the visuals &#8212; we are very conscious of that. And the people that we&#8217;re going to and asking for what works for you and what doesn&#8217;t, is primarily girls,&#8221; he adds.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2122285\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2122285\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2122285\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_Craft_Trade.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"383\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_Craft_Trade.png 1920w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_Craft_Trade.png?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_Craft_Trade.png?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_Craft_Trade.png?resize=768,432 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_Craft_Trade.png?resize=680,383 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_Craft_Trade.png?resize=1536,864 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_Craft_Trade.png?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2122285\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> WildWorks<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Building off the Animal Jam fan base has been an advantage for getting Fer.al off the ground. Today, Animal Jam has anywhere between 2.5 million to 4 million monthly active users out of a total of 135 million registered accounts. The gulf between the registered and active figures is indicative of how many kids have grown out of Animal Jam since its October 2010 launch. But Stacey admits the title has seen some decline since its peak usage, as well.<\/p>\n<p>Still, there&#8217;s a lot of interest in what WildWorks does next, it seems.<\/p>\n<p>Within a week of launching the Fer.al website, the game had 75,000 kids sign up to become beta testers. The testers were brought into the beta slowly, starting in April 2020, and initially on desktop only. Now, the beta version of the game sees daily actives in the low 10,000&#8217;s pre-launch. On the Apple App Store and Google Play, over 100,000 people have registered for the pre-release, as well.<\/p>\n<p>Like Animal Jam, Fer.al will offer a freemium experience. But while Animal Jam generated nearly 80% of revenues through subscriptions, Fer.al will use a season pass model of monetization. Users buy the season &#8212; priced around $10 to $20 &#8212; via an in-app purchase, which will unlock unique items and experiences specific to that season. It expects to launch around seven seasons per year.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2122289\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2122289\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2122289\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_SanctuaryDesign.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"383\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_SanctuaryDesign.png 1920w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_SanctuaryDesign.png?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_SanctuaryDesign.png?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_SanctuaryDesign.png?resize=768,432 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_SanctuaryDesign.png?resize=680,383 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_SanctuaryDesign.png?resize=1536,864 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Feral_SanctuaryDesign.png?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2122289\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> WildWorks<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>The company didn&#8217;t offer seasons until later in the beta test, but Stacey says the conversion rate was at &#8220;the high end of our expectations so far on desktop.&#8221; If the mobile conversion rates remain as high as desktop, it will be in the range to start investing in user acquisition, he says. The company may also consider ads at a later date as well as merchandise, if all goes well.<\/p>\n<p>Salt Lake City-headquartered WildWorks (formerly Smart Bomb Interactive) is majority owned by Signal Peak Ventures, which has invested $20+ million into the company over the years. The company shifted in 2008 to focus on its own IP, resulting in the launch of Animal Jam and other titles.<\/p>\n<p>Over the past few years, WildWorks&#8217; revenue &#8212; largely from Animal Jam and another game, Tag with Ryan &#8212; has ranged between $20+ million to below $30 million. If Fer.al is able to successfully capture the Animal Jam graduates who are looking to move up to &#8220;older kid&#8221; gameplay, it could grow that revenue base by a sizable amount.<\/p>\n<p>Fer.al is launching publicly today in all countries and will be available initially in English. It can be played on PC, Mac, iOS and Android.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"z5MakaokFP\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/19\/6-investors-on-2021s-mobile-gaming-trends-and-opportunities\/\">6 investors on 2021&#8217;s mobile gaming trends and opportunities<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;6 investors on 2021&#8217;s mobile gaming trends and opportunities&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/19\/6-investors-on-2021s-mobile-gaming-trends-and-opportunities\/embed\/#?secret=z5MakaokFP\" data-secret=\"z5MakaokFP\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<hr \/>\n<p><em><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/26\/techcrunch-early-stage-is-the-startup-bootcamp-youve-always-needed\/?tpcc=ECTW2020\">Early Stage<\/a> is the premier \u2018how-to\u2019 event for startup entrepreneurs and investors. You\u2019ll hear firsthand how some of the most successful founders and VCs build their businesses, raise money and manage their portfolios. We\u2019ll cover every aspect of company building: Fundraising, recruiting, sales, product-market fit, PR, marketing and brand building. Each session also has audience participation built in \u2014 there\u2019s ample time included for audience questions and start in online social gaming with a game like Animal Jam. glimpse inside the minds of tech&#8217;s DEI leaders"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Diversity and inclusion as an idea has been on the agenda of tech companies for years now. But the industry still lacks true inclusion, despite best efforts put forth by heads of diversity, equity and inclusion at these companies.<\/p>\n<p>At TC Sessions: Justice, I spoke with Uber Chief Diversity Officer Bo Young Lee and Netflix VP of Inclusion Strategy for Product Wade Davis about the work that still needs to be done, the effects of California&#8217;s Proposition 22 and more.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<h3>On last summer&#8217;s racial justice uprising<\/h3>\n<p>Last summer, after the murder of George Floyd and the subsequent collective consciousness around racial injustice in the U.S., many tech companies spoke out about racism and equality. Davis said he was happy to see more people speaking about those issues but also a bit frustrated that &#8220;it takes something like that for folks to get truly engaged.&#8221;<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<blockquote><p><strong>Davis: <\/strong>And inside of Netflix, one of the things that I was really intentional about is to tell our employees who are not Black, right, to not ask our employees how they feel but for them to be much more introspective of what it felt like for them, right, as a white person, or however they identify for them to do the introspection. Because that&#8217;s what it means to be an ally &#8212; to not put the labor on the group that is already feeling the impact and the oppression. And what we found was that many of our employees, for the first time had to wrestle with like, what it means to be white. What it means to be in a situation where you are seeing someone who looks like you take the life of someone who looks like me. So we really tried to switch the actual narrative and the conversation to not add more labor and trauma on our Black employees. <strong><em>(Timestamp: 1:10)<\/em><\/strong><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>Lee said she was a bit skeptical at the time because we&#8217;ve seen this type of response before in light of the violent killings of Black people.<\/p>\n<blockquote><p><strong>Lee: <\/strong>And then within a few weeks you see that interest and that focus wane once more. So I was skeptical that the enthusiasm would continue and enthusiasm in a way to try to solve all of our racism problems in a short period of time. I was surprised that it did continue. <strong><em>(Timestamp: 3:31)<\/em><\/strong><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>In her conversations with her counterparts at Uber, Lee said she wanted to make sure that the company didn&#8217;t make such a wide commitment that &#8220;those commitments became nothing more than virtue signaling at the end of the day.&#8221;<\/p>\n<blockquote><p><strong>Lee: <\/strong>I said to my leadership, if you really want to come out and make some bold statements about being anti-racist, I&#8217;m going to create almost a litmus test to make sure that you really understand what that means because I don&#8217;t want to go up as a company to say we&#8217;re going to be anti-racist and then do nothing about it because that just relives and rehashes the injustices that we&#8217;ve seen in the past. <strong><em>(Timestamp: 4:25)<\/em><\/strong><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>So when Uber&#8217;s first post-anti-racism diversity report came out, and it showed Uber&#8217;s Black employee base declined, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/11\/20\/despite-focus-on-anti-racism-ubers-black-employee-base-has-decreased\/\">Lee said at the time that was not acceptable<\/a>.<\/p>\n<blockquote><p><strong>Lee: <\/strong>I think part of the commitments we made around being really anti-racist is transparency at all costs, even when we know that transparency could potentially make us look, not reflect as positively on us. So the question did go back, as you know, when we were putting together our diversity report is, &#8216;wow, these numbers are not where we want them to be. None of us are happy about it.&#8217; But in our commitment of being accountable, you know, we want the public to hold us accountable. We want to hold people accountable, we want to be accountable to our workforce, we&#8217;re going to be as transparent about why that decline in black employees happened and underrepresented people happened, what the cause was and what we are doing. <strong><em>(Timestamp: 6:11)<\/em><\/strong><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<ul>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/11\/20\/despite-focus-on-anti-racism-ubers-black-employee-base-has-decreased\/\">Despite commitment to anti-racism, Uber\u2019s Black employee base has decreased<\/a><\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<hr \/>\n<h3><span data-sheets-value=\"{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;&quot;}\" data-sheets-userformat=\"{&quot;2&quot;:12801,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;12&quot;:0,&quot;15&quot;:&quot;Open Sans&quot;,&quot;16&quot;:12}\">On being early in the DEI journey<\/span><\/h3>\n<p>Netflix, despite having previously reported diversity numbers, only released its <a href=\"https:\/\/about.netflix.com\/en\/news\/netflix-inclusion-report-2021\">first official diversity report this year<\/a>. That&#8217;s partly because the team has only been in place for the last three years, Davis said.<\/p>\n<blockquote><p><strong>Davis: <\/strong>So we&#8217;re still at the awareness building phase, like from a foundational standpoint, and we&#8217;re really trying to double down so that folks know why I&amp;D matters. Like, what it actually is, and how it impacts all of us. Because oftentimes, folks think of all of these isms and phobias as something that happens to other people. But if we can really make folks understand that there&#8217;s a cost to all these isms, and phobias to all of us individually, interpersonally, culturally and institutionally, then it makes it easier down the road when folks start to feel somewhat fatigued, right? Because there is always that fatigue factor. So we&#8217;re really trying to get ahead of that. And to have folks to think through like, what is in it for me, and what is in it for my colleagues. <strong><em>(Timestamp: 17:33)<\/em><\/strong><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<ul>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/06\/17\/the-future-of-diversity-and-inclusion-in-tech\/\">The future of diversity and inclusion in tech<\/a><\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<h3>Sharing the DEI load<\/h3>\n<p>Too often does the work of DEI fall on just a handful of people. At Netflix, Davis said it&#8217;s important that there is a shared load, and that all of its leaders are able to speak to the importance of diversity at the company.<\/p>\n<blockquote><p><strong>Davis: <\/strong>And I would say our other largest goal is to make sure that all of our leaders can speak to the importance of AI and be more than just a talking point. So how do we build a model that&#8217;s a train the trainer model, where each of our leaders has a one to one inclusion coach, which requires them to have monthly sit-downs with their inclusion partner, where they go on a real intensive journey, so that they can understand how does their leadership style need to evolve and adapt and expand and flex to meet the needs of a larger set of individuals and not the historical ones who folks have engaged with? And we found that to put our leaders on the spot, so that when someone calls me to give a talk, I can say &#8216;No, our COO Greg Peters is just as competent and capable to sit on this panel about inclusion as I am.&#8217; And we feel that we&#8217;re modeling and signaling to our entire organization that this is not just a nice to have, but it&#8217;s part and parcel to your success as an employee, as a leader and to our success as an organization. <strong><em>(Timestamp: 18:26)<\/em><\/strong><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"m0sH0JqoLH\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/12\/30\/on-the-diversity-front-2020-may-prove-a-tipping-point\/\">On the diversity front, 2020 may prove a tipping point<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;On the diversity front, 2020 may prove a tipping point&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/12\/30\/on-the-diversity-front-2020-may-prove-a-tipping-point\/embed\/#?secret=m0sH0JqoLH\" data-secret=\"m0sH0JqoLH\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<hr \/>\n<h3>On Prop 22&#8217;s impact on people of color<\/h3>\n<p>Prop 22 went into effect in California earlier this year after a contentious battle where one side, including Uber, Lyft and other tech companies, wanted workers to remain independent contractors and the other side wanted gig workers to be made employees and therefore entitled to more benefits. Prop 22&#8217;s passage was a win for Uber and its counterparts, which collectively spent north of $200 million on its campaign efforts.<\/p>\n<p>Some have wondered how Uber can reconcile its commitment to anti-racism given that many gig workers are people of color. Lee, however, pushed back on that characterization.<\/p>\n<blockquote><p><strong>Lee: <\/strong>I would challenge some of those that believe that Prop 22 actually disproportionately hurts people of color. If you actually look at the way the civil rights organizations that came out in support of Prop 22, the NAACP of Northern California and Hawaii came out in support of Prop 22, most of the Hispanic civil rights organizations as well. <strong><em>(Timestamp: 24:59)<\/em><\/strong><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>Prop 22, of course, was in response to the passage of AB 5, which set new standards of worker classification that were designed to make it harder for companies to classify workers as independent contractors.<\/p>\n<blockquote><p><strong>Lee:\u00a0<\/strong>And you looked at the way those exceptions were being made to AB 5, you saw that the exceptions were disproportionately being made for those IC &#8212; you know, independent contractor roles that were predominantly represented by white workers. And they were all getting exceptions from AB 5. And then you look at the roles that were predominantly represented by people of color, especially underrepresented people of color, and those roles were not getting exceptions in AB 5. [&#8230;] For me, how I define racism isn&#8217;t based on intent but it&#8217;s based on impact. And when I see that kind of level of disparate, disproportionate impact, that&#8217;s when I think about, you know, what is racist or not. So I would challenge this notion that [Prop 22] actually disproportionately hurt people of color, especially given that we had civil rights organizations that said we support Prop 22. So, I don&#8217;t think there&#8217;s anything that really needs to be reconciled, from my perspective and from the organization&#8217;s perspective.\u00a0<em><strong>(Timestamp: 24:59)<\/strong><\/em><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<ul>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/03\/ca-supreme-court-denies-lawsuit-challenging-prop-22s-constitutionality\/\">CA Supreme Court denies lawsuit challenging Prop 22\u2019s constitutionality<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/15\/uber-lobbies-for-prop-22-style-gig-work-standards-in-the-eu\/\">Uber lobbies for \u2018Prop 22\u2019-style gig work standards in the EU<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/12\/13\/an-even-bigger-battle-for-gig-worker-rights-is-on-the-horizon\/\">An even bigger battle for gig worker rights is on the horizon<\/a><\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<p><span data-sheets-value=\"{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;&quot;}\" data-sheets-userformat=\"{&quot;2&quot;:12801,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;12&quot;:0,&quot;15&quot;:&quot;Open Sans&quot;,&quot;16&quot;:12}\"> <div embedded-video-placeholder=\"60400dc3303d501d18141bbc\" post-id=\"2120707\"><\/div> <\/span><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/otter.ai\/u\/zN--5q60dfqViVw9Tfh4fJwG0as\">You can read the entire transcript here<\/a>.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p><em><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/26\/techcrunch-early-stage-is-the-startup-bootcamp-youve-always-needed\/?tpcc=ECTW2020\">Early Stage<\/a> is the premier &#8220;how-to&#8221; event for startup entrepreneurs and investors. You\u2019ll hear firsthand how some of the most successful founders and VCs build their businesses, raise money and manage their portfolios. We\u2019ll cover every aspect of company building: Fundraising, recruiting, sales, product-market fit, PR, marketing and brand building. Each session also has audience participation built-in &#8212; there\u2019s ample time included for audience questions and discussion.<\/em><\/p>\n<p>\t<iframe\n\t\t\tid=\"wpcom-iframe-dde292b93a5f3017145419dd51bb9fce\"\n\t\t\twidth=\"99%\"\n\t\t\theight=\"1500\"\n\t\t\tsrc=\"https:\/\/tcprotectedembed.com\/protected-iframe\/dde292b93a5f3017145419dd51bb9fce\"\n\t\t\tscrolling=\"true\"\n\t\t\tframeborder=\"0\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"wpcom-protected-iframe\"\n\t>\n\t<\/iframe>\n\t<script
