2021","slug":"tc-sessions-justice-2021","taxonomy":"tc_event","rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event\/576821871"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/tc_event"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event\/449559507"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tc_event=576821871"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_events?tc_event=576821871"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tc_event=576821871"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}]]}},{"id":2122300,"date":"2021-03-08T08:22:04","date_gmt":"2021-03-08T16:22:04","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2122300"},"modified":"2021-03-08T12:09:53","modified_gmt":"2021-03-08T20:09:53","slug":"teslas-utility-scale-batteries-are-coming-to-texas","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/teslas-utility-scale-batteries-are-coming-to-texas\/","title":{"rendered":"Tesla\u2019s utility-scale batteries are coming to Texas\u00a0"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Elon Musk is bringing his utility-scale battery ambitions to the Lone Star state.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">An under-the-radar Tesla subsidiary has been at work building a 100 MW energy storage project in Angleton, Texas, according to an application with the Public Utilities Commission of Texas, and other documents. Bloomberg was <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.bloomberg.com\/news\/features\/2021-03-08\/tesla-is-plugging-a-secret-mega-battery-into-the-texas-grid\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">the first to report<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> on the documents and link a previously unknown subsidiary to Tesla.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Gambit Energy Storage LLC applied for an application with the Public Utilities Commission of Texas, the regulatory body charged with overseeing the state\u2019s electric utilities, in June of last year. Gambit said in the application, viewed by TechCrunch, that it intends to provide wholesale electricity and grid-balancing services on the Energy Reliability Council of Texas grid. The project is located in Angleton, a town about 50 miles west of Galveston near the Gulf Coast.\u00a0<\/span><\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"H01lVkIETm\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/24\/can-solid-state-batteries-power-up-for-the-next-generation-of-evs\/\">Can solid state batteries power up for the next generation of EVs?<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Can solid state batteries power up for the next generation of EVs?&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/24\/can-solid-state-batteries-power-up-for-the-next-generation-of-evs\/embed\/#?secret=H01lVkIETm\" data-secret=\"H01lVkIETm\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The project\u2019s proposed date of commercial operation is June 1, according to reporting from Bloomberg.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The Texas grid has been under the microscope since mid-February, when an unprecedented blast of Arctic weather knocked 46,000 MW of power off line at its peak \u2014 more than a third of the system\u2019s overall generation capacity. The disaster left millions of Texans in sub-freezing temperatures for days. The ERCOT board of directors fired its CEO and the chair of the PUCT resigned in the wake of the catastrophe, while legislators at the capital mull major changes to Texas power market operations.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Tesla already has contracts for battery storage systems with California Utilities Southern California Edison and PG&amp;E, but this is the company\u2019s first major project elsewhere.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p><em><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/26\/techcrunch-early-stage-is-the-startup-bootcamp-youve-always-needed\/?tpcc=ECTW2020\">Early Stage<\/a> is the premier &#8220;how-to&#8221; event for startup entrepreneurs and investors. You\u2019ll hear firsthand how some of the most successful founders and VCs build their businesses, raise money and manage their portfolios. We\u2019ll cover every aspect of company building: Fundraising, recruiting, sales, product-market fit, PR, marketing and brand building. Each session also has audience participation built-in &#8212; there\u2019s ample time included for audience questions and discussion.<\/em><\/p>\n<p>\t<iframe\n\t\t\tid=\"wpcom-iframe-dde292b93a5f3017145419dd51bb9fce\"\n\t\t\twidth=\"99%\"\n\t\t\theight=\"1500\"\n\t\t\tsrc=\"https:\/\/tcprotectedembed.com\/protected-iframe\/dde292b93a5f3017145419dd51bb9fce\"\n\t\t\tscrolling=\"true\"\n\t\t\tframeborder=\"0\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"wpcom-protected-iframe\"\n\t>\n\t<\/iframe>\n\t<script allery?categories=2401"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=2401"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":24973,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/batteries\/","name":"Batteries","slug":"batteries","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/24973"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=24973"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=24973"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=24973"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=24973"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":1244446,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/elon-musk\/","name":"Elon Musk","slug":"elon-musk","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/1244446"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=1244446"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=1244446"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=1244446"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=1244446"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576862033,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/gambit-energy-storage\/","name":"Gambit Energy Storage","slug":"gambit-energy-storage","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576862033"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576862033"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576862033"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576862033"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576862033"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":429989,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/tesla\/","name":"Tesla","slug":"tesla","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/429989"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=429989"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=429989"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=429989"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=429989"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2122280,"date":"2021-03-08T08:21:12","date_gmt":"2021-03-08T16:21:12","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2122280"},"modified":"2021-03-08T12:01:49","modified_gmt":"2021-03-08T20:01:49","slug":"vendr-raises-huge-60m-series-a-as-its-saas-purchasing-service-scales","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/vendr-raises-huge-60m-series-a-as-its-saas-purchasing-service-scales\/","title":{"rendered":"Vendr raises huge $60M Series A as its SaaS-purchasing service scales"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">This morning <a href=\"https:\/\/www.vendr.com\/\">Vendr<\/a> announced a $60 million Series A round, a huge funding event led by Tiger Global, with participation from Y Combinator, Sound Ventures, Craft Ventures, F-Prime Capital and Garage Capital.<\/p>\n<p>The outsized Series A comes after Vendr <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/06\/10\/vendr-raises-4m-from-david-sackss-craft-ventures-to-reduce-saas-bills\/\">last raised $4 million in a mid-2020 seed round<\/a>, with TechCrunch reporting that the company was profitable at the time. Vendr had raised just over $6 million total before this latest round.<\/p>\n<p>TechCrunch had a few questions. First, how the company had managed to attract so much capital so quickly. According to an interview with Vendr CEO <a href=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/ryanneu\/\">Ryan Neu<\/a>, his startup grew just under 5x in 2020, and was cash flow-positive last year as well. The startup&#8217;s model of standing between SaaS buyers and sellers, speeding up transactions while lowering their cost, appears to have fit well into 2020&#8217;s twin trends of rising software reliance and a focus on cost control.<\/p>\n<p>Second, how did the company manage to grow so much? Vendr charges its customers between 1% and 5% of their software spend that it manages, which can add up. Neu told TechCrunch that a somewhat standard 500-person company might spend $2 million to $3.5 million on software each year, which by our math would make that company worth no less than $20,000 to $35,000 in revenue for Vendr at 1% of spend. At Vendr&#8217;s midpoint 2.5%, those figures rise $50,000 to $87,500.<\/p>\n<p>At those prices, Vendr can stack up annual revenue pretty quickly. But why would Vendr customers pay it to handle their software spend? Savings, effectively. So long as they save more than Vendr charges, they are coming out ahead. And as the startup claims that it can cut the time to buying, its own customers can reduce time spent on securing tooling.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"blSstaS2gm\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/02\/the-future-of-saas-is-on-demand-use-experts-to-drive-growth-and-engagement\/\">The future of SaaS is on-demand: Use experts to drive growth and engagement<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;The future of SaaS is on-demand: Use experts to drive growth and engagement&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/02\/the-future-of-saas-is-on-demand-use-experts-to-drive-growth-and-engagement\/embed\/#?secret=blSstaS2gm\" data-secret=\"blSstaS2gm\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>Everyone wins, it seems, except for software sellers. After all, they are the ones losing a chance to get less-sophisticated buyers to pay more for their code, right? Neu said that his company&#8217;s model isn&#8217;t too bad for selling companies as they close deals much more quickly, at a higher rate of closure. That could save their sales team time, which might help balance the price differential.<\/p>\n<p>Pressed on what Vendr might be able to do for the selling side of the software market given its present-day buyer focus, Neu declined to share any possible plans.<\/p>\n<p>Returning to the round, why did Vendr raise the money at all if it was doing just fine sans new external funding? The company told TechCrunch that it has scaled its staff to 60 from 10 a year ago, and that it wanted a stronger balance sheet. That&#8217;s fine. We&#8217;d be hard-pressed to find the startup that wouldn&#8217;t take such a large check from Tiger, given the valuation gain the raise implies for Vendr, so there isn&#8217;t too much mystery to unpack.<\/p>\n<p>A theme that TechCrunch has explored in recent weeks has been the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/15\/rapid-growth-in-2020-reveals-okr-software-markets-untapped-potential\/\">huge depth of the software market<\/a>. Given the TAM for bits and bytes, Vendr may be able to keep up the hypergrowth that its new round implies its investors will expect. Let&#8217;s see how 2021 winds up for the company.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"1rLq9sF9G5\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/15\/rapid-growth-in-2020-reveals-okr-software-markets-untapped-potential\/\">Rapid growth in 2020 reveals OKR software market&#8217;s untapped potential<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Rapid growth in 2020 reveals OKR software market&#8217;s untapped potential&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/15\/rapid-growth-in-2020-reveals-okr-software-markets-untapped-potential\/embed\/#?secret=1rLq9sF9G5\" data-secret=\"1rLq9sF9G5\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<hr \/>\n<p><em><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/26\/techcrunch-early-stage-is-the-startup-bootcamp-youve-always-needed\/?tpcc=ECTW2020\">Early Stage<\/a> is the premier &#8220;how-to&#8221; event for startup entrepreneurs and investors. You\u2019ll hear firsthand how some of the most successful founders and VCs build their businesses, raise money and manage their portfolios. We\u2019ll cover every aspect of company building: Fundraising, recruiting, sales, product-market fit, PR, marketing and brand building. Each session also has audience participation built-in &#8212; there\u2019s ample time included for audience questions and discussion.<\/em><\/p>\n<p>\t<iframe\n\t\t\tid=\"wpcom-iframe-dde292b93a5f3017145419dd51bb9fce\"\n\t\t\twidth=\"99%\"\n\t\t\theight=\"1500\"\n\t\t\tsrc=\"https:\/\/tcprotectedembed.com\/protected-iframe\/dde292b93a5f3017145419dd51bb9fce\"\n\t\t\tscrolling=\"true\"\n\t\t\tframeborder=\"0\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"wpcom-protected-iframe\"\n\t>\n\t<\/iframe>\n\t<script ":"Vendr","slug":"vendr","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576692167"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576692167"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576692167"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576692167"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576692167"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":66455,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/y-combinator\/","name":"Y Combinator","slug":"y-combinator","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/66455"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=66455"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=66455"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=66455"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=66455"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2122236,"date":"2021-03-08T07:56:45","date_gmt":"2021-03-08T15:56:45","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2122236"},"modified":"2021-03-08T10:16:24","modified_gmt":"2021-03-08T18:16:24","slug":"olos-ipo-could-value-the-company-north-of-3b-as-toast-waits-in-the-wings","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/olos-ipo-could-value-the-company-north-of-3b-as-toast-waits-in-the-wings\/","title":{"rendered":"Olo&#8217;s IPO could value the company north of $3B as Toast waits in the wings"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\"><a href=\"https:\/\/www.olo.com\/\">Olo<\/a>, the New<\/span> York-based fintech startup that provides order processing software to restaurants, shared its initial IPO price range this morning. The company&#8217;s debut comes ahead of <a href=\"https:\/\/www.wsj.com\/articles\/restaurant-software-provider-toast-prepares-for-ipo-11613938981?mod=hp_lista_pos2\">the expected IPO of Toast<\/a>, a Boston-based unicorn with a similar market remit.<\/p>\n<p>Targeting $16 to $18 per share, Olo could raise as much as $372.6 million in its public offering.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p><strong><em>The Exchange explores startups, markets and money. Read it <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/subscribe\/?tpcc=theexchange\">every morning on Extra Crunch<\/a>, or get <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/newsletters\">The Exchange newsletter<\/a> every Saturday.<\/em><\/strong><\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p>Unlike most companies going public in recent quarters that we&#8217;ve tracked, Olo has a history of growth and profitability, making its impending pricing all the more interesting. It&#8217;s unknown if Toast is profitable, but because most venture-backed IPOs aren&#8217;t, we&#8217;re presuming it isn&#8217;t.<\/p>\n<p>This morning, we&#8217;re doing our usual work: parsing the company&#8217;s pricing interval to get a valuation range for Olo. We&#8217;ll calculate both simple and fully diluted pricing and then do some quick work on its revenue scale to come to grips with its total scale.<\/p>\n<p>Are investors willing to pay more for profits? And, if so, how much? This is a niche question because most IPOs look a bit more like Coursera than Olo, but it&#8217;s still worth answering.<\/p>\n<h2>Olo&#8217;s IPO valuation range<\/h2>\n<p>If you&#8217;d like to follow along, you can read the new S-1 filing <a href=\"https:\/\/www.sec.gov\/Archives\/edgar\/data\/0001431695\/000119312521072308\/d867519ds1a.htm\">here<\/a>. Our <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/24\/understanding-toasts-expected-ipo-through-the-lens-of-olos-2020-results\/\">first look at Olo is here<\/a>, and its fundraising history is <a href=\"https:\/\/www.crunchbase.com\/organization\/olo\">here<\/a>, per Crunchbase.<\/p>\n<p>The company is targeting $16 to $18 per share with an expected sale of 18 million shares. The company is also reserving 2.7 million shares for its underwriters. At the upper end of its range, not counting shares reserved for its bankers, Olo could raise $324 million in its debut.<\/p>\n<p>Per the company, its total number of Class A and B shares outstanding after its IPO would come to 142,012,926, or what we calculate to be 144,712,926 shares, including its underwriters&#8217; option. Using the latter \u2014 because we tend to look for valuation extremes \u2014 Olo would be worth $2.32 billion to $2.6 billion.<\/p>\n<p>But what about its fully diluted valuation? Adding in shares that are currently tied to unexercised but vested stock options bring Olo to around 188,085,714 shares. Add in the underwriters&#8217; option and the total rises to 190,785,714 shares.<\/p>\n<p>Using the latter figure, at $16 and $18 per share Olo could be worth $3.05 billion to $3.43 billion on a fully diluted basis.<\/p>\n<h2>Is that expensive?<\/h2>\n<p>Let&#8217;s find out! Digging back into Olo&#8217;s growth, we can see a business with rapidly expanding software incomes. And the same software revenues are improving in quality over time. From 2019 to 2020, for example, Olo&#8217;s &#8220;platform&#8221; revenues \u2014 a mix of subscription and transaction top line from software \u2014 grew from $45.1 million to $92.8 million. Over the same time, the company&#8217;s platform revenue saw its gross margin improve from 73.6% to 84.5%.<div class=\"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Targeting $16 to $18 per share, Olo could raise as much as $372.6 million in its public offering.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":428363,"featured_media":1996009,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"outcome":"","status":"","crunchbase_tag":0,"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"b4d64207-1b73-3a1b-91c1-c2b336909a65"},"categories":[60523764,20429],"tags":[576848238,576847237,18477,576765839,18623],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[576796353,576796356],"tc_event":[],"jetpack_featured_media_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/NSussman_Techcrunch_Exchange_v3-GRN.jpg","shortlink":"https:\/\/tcrn.ch\/30lJxM3","rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"premiumContent":true,"premiumCutoffPercent":0.55,"featured":false,"subtitle":"","seoTitle":"","seoDescription":"","tc_cb_mapping":[],"associatedEvent":null,"event":null,"authors":[1461024],"hide_featured_image":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2122236"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/types\/post"}],"replies":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/comments?post=2122236"}],"version-history":[{"count":10,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2122236\/revisions"}],"predecessor-version":[{"id":2122404,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2122236\/revisions\/2122404"}],"authors":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/guest-authors\/alex-wilhelm"}],"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/edit":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-admin\/post.php?post=2122236&action=edit"}],"author":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/428363"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/media\/1996009"}],"wp:attachment":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\ Exchange","slug":"the-exchange","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576765839"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576765839"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576765839"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576765839"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576765839"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":18623,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/toast\/","name":"toast","slug":"toast","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/18623"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=18623"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=18623"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=18623"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=18623"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[{"id":576796353,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/extracrunch\/fundraising\/","name":"Fundraising","slug":"fundraising","taxonomy":"tc_ec_category","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category\/576796353"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/tc_ec_category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tc_ec_category=576796353"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576796356,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/extracrunch\/market-analysis\/","name":"Market Analysis","slug":"market-analysis","taxonomy":"tc_ec_category","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category\/576796356"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/tc_ec_category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tc_ec_category=576796356"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[]]}},{"id":2121723,"date":"2021-03-08T07:50:38","date_gmt":"2021-03-08T15:50:38","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2121723"},"modified":"2021-03-08T11:53:25","modified_gmt":"2021-03-08T19:53:25","slug":"investors-discuss-alt-financing-and-the-role-of-venture-capital","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/investors-discuss-alt-financing-and-the-role-of-venture-capital\/","title":{"rendered":"Investors discuss alt-financing and the role of venture capital"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">There are so many ways to secure capital for your startup beyond traditional venture capital, from crowdfunding to debt financings to revenue-share agreements. But is all money created equal if you are on route to becoming a billion-dollar business? Dr. Astrid Scholz, the co-founder of Zebras Unite; Sydney Thomas, a principal at Precursor Ventures; and Brian Brackeen, the founding partner of Lightship Capital, joined us at TC Sessions: Justice to discuss alternative pathways to funding, and if the democratization of capital is a fa\u00e7ade.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<h3><strong>On the choice to stay away from traditional venture capital<\/strong><\/h3>\n<p>Scholz is currently building out Zebras Unite, a founder-led cooperative that is focused on making startups more sustainable, ethical and inclusive. During the panel, she mentioned that the capital arm of Zebras Unite could have been a traditional fund, but the organization ultimately decided to pursue more creative alternatives, such as the <a href=\"https:\/\/zebrasunite.coop\/capital-services\">Future Economy Lab<\/a>. This lab, which focuses on helping founders find financing instruments that fit their sectors, took place in Montreal with a focus on climate tech.<\/p>\n<p>Scholz shared why she went this route, versus a traditional fund:<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<blockquote><p>In the big scheme of things, [VC] really is just a tiny drop in the large capital pool of capital that&#8217;s out there. And then on the other extreme, you have bank loans. That may or may not be accessible to startup founders, especially if they&#8217;re from certain demographics in this country. Of course we have a massive racial wealth gap and access to capital.<\/p>\n<p>To me, that sounds just like two flavors of capital: vanilla and chocolate. It&#8217;s not interesting, if that was an ice cream store, it was not interesting. At Zebras Unite, we&#8217;re looking to increase the diversity of capital, as well as the diversity of managers of capital. So we&#8217;re very interested in revenue-based financing mechanisms. We&#8217;re very interested in non-dilutive early-stage forms of support to entrepreneurs who don&#8217;t have friends and family wealth. We were looking at new sorts of character-based lending instruments and a bunch of blended approaches, so there&#8217;s more room on the capital spectrum to color in, beyond the two ends of the spectrum. <em><strong>(Timestamp: 3:52)<\/strong><\/em><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<ul>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/04\/sec-loosens-crowdfunding-regs-so-small-businesses-can-raise-alternative-financing-in-pandemic\/\">SEC loosens crowdfunding regs so small businesses can raise alternative financing in pandemic<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/09\/08\/angellist-pioneers-rolling-vc-funds-in-pivot-to-saas\/\">AngelList pioneers rolling VC funds in pivot to SaaS<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/08\/19\/who-are-the-major-revenue-based-investing-vcs\/\">Who are the major revenue-based investing VCs?<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/26\/how-to-approach-and-work-with-the-3-types-of-corporate-vcs\/\">How to approach (and work with) the 3 types of corporate VCs<\/a><\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<hr \/>\n<h3><strong>On why venture capital paths can be formed around a more inclusive strategy<\/strong><\/h3>\n<p>Now, venture capital isn\u2019t the devil, and in a market as hot as right now it\u2019s clear that there is a huge demand to back great ideas. The problem starts when you look at which ideas get backed versus which don\u2019t, and underrepresented founders lose out at a disproportionately higher rate than white founders.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"O9udKYybo4\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/07\/07\/8-black-investors-discuss-the-intersection-of-race-tech-and-vc\/\">8 Black investors discuss the intersection of race, tech and funding<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;8 Black investors discuss the intersection of race, tech and funding&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/07\/07\/8-black-investors-discuss-the-intersection-of-race-tech-and-vc\/embed\/#?secret=O9udKYybo4\" data-secret=\"O9udKYybo4\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>Standards help everyone get on the same page, and in venture, any clarity around how one investor cuts checks versus another can help curb signaling risk and help set expectations on early-stage founders. Lightship Capital uses traditional venture capital but applies it in a way Brackeen thinks is more inclusive to founders.<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>Oftentimes, VCs talk about designing your product for your customer, but then they don&#8217;t design themselves around the customer. They completely ignore what they tell people to do. And so we&#8217;re designed for the underrepresented founders. And for us, that&#8217;s women, minorities, LGBTQ, plus disabled. And so the capital path for that founder is different from the white-male Zuckerberg founder. Oftentimes, a Series A is very, very difficult, so we bridge that. We\u2019ll write a smaller check &#8212; half a million dollars first &#8212; and then we\u2019ll reserve $1.5 million so they can go out and get a Series A done. And so to do that, we don&#8217;t require board seats and things of that nature, we do require strong collaboration<em>. <strong>(Timestamp: 7:03)<\/strong><\/em><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<ul>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/06\/revenue-based-financing-the-next-step-for-private-equity-and-early-stage-investment\/\">Flexible VC: A new model for startups targeting profitability<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/10\/10\/venture-capital-gets-less-diverse-in-2020\/\">Venture capital gets less diverse in 2020<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/06\/09\/if-youre-not-investing-in-diverse-founders-youre-a-bad-investor\/\">If you\u2019re not investing in diverse founders, you\u2019re a bad investor<\/a><\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<hr \/>\n<h3><strong>On how your first check could impact your next check <\/strong><\/h3>\n<p>Thomas noted that Indie.vc, an alternative financing program that was aimed at slow-growth, bootstrapped founders, shutting down this past week could be a lesson for founders who look to finance their companies from the plethora of programs out there.<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>They were at the frontiers of building access to new capital. I think one of the things that we saw when we would talk to founders who were considering Indie.vc capital versus our capital was, \u2018does the investor that you would like after you get that Indie.vc funding, if you decide to go to a more traditional VC firm? Can they actually even do revenue based financing investments, some people actually legitimately can&#8217;t because of the regulatory limits of their fund.<em><strong>(Timestamp: 16:28)<\/strong><\/em><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>She went on to explain how this isn\u2019t simply a one-off problem that could happen with. Precursor founding partner Charles Hudson penned a post, months ago, about the <a href=\"https:\/\/www.charleshudson.net\/we-only-have-100-points-of-equity-to-split-up\">messiness in early-stage cap tables. <\/a><\/p>\n<blockquote><p>I don&#8217;t want to say it&#8217;s unfair, but you have to make a pretty final decision, pretty early on in what type of company you want to build. And I don&#8217;t think that allows for a lot of the flexibility that is the reality of building a startup. When you pivot like five to 10 to 20 to 30 times before you finally get to something that, you know, matters. And so how do we also allow for more flexibility between multiple different types of revenue structures? I just don\u2019t think that exists right now. <strong>(Timestamp: 17:12) <\/strong><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<ul>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/07\/10\/a-recapitalization-reckoning\/\">A recapitalization reckoning<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/11\/23\/founders-seeking-their-first-check-need-a-fundraising-sales-funnel\/\">Founders seeking their first check need a fundraising sales funnel<\/a><\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<p>Brackeen added that his form loves non-dilutive financing before, and after, they are nicest. Pitch competitions might help a startup launch, but it won\u2019t help founders get from stage to stage. This banter basically answers the question that I set early on: is all capital created equal in the eyes of investors? A cap table filled with different types of financing structures and notes, as Thomas mentions, could lead to your next check investor declining to invest based on a semantic versus a lack of believing in your vision. One side effect we see here is <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/07\/10\/a-recapitalization-reckoning\/\">recapitalizations<\/a>, an event where startups restructure their entire cap table to squeeze out old investors, bring on new ones and shift the way equity and debt is managed.<\/p>\n<p>Scholz chimed in about how startups should think about capital limitations, but also other corporate structures that could shape the trajectory of a startup.<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>I think that point about founders basically getting locked into a corporate structure and an investment strategy before they even really know what they&#8217;re building or how it&#8217;s selling is just so important. I always joke, you know, like 99 out of 100 corporate lawyers will tell you to incorporate as a Delaware C. [But] that may or may not be the right answer. There may be a good reason to become a cooperative, and incorporating as a Delaware C will make your life very difficult.<strong> (Timestamp: 17:46)<\/strong><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<ul>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2016\/10\/02\/should-your-startup-take-the-b-corp-route\/\">Should your startup take the public benefit or B corp route?<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/03\/08\/which-types-of-startups-are-most-often-profitable\/\">Which types of startups are most often profitable?<\/a><\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<hr \/>\n<h3><strong>On if VC will be even more relevant five years from now<\/strong><\/h3>\n<p>The conversation turned into a broader discussion on if venture capital will be as relevant five years from now as it is today. While Scholz said that she doesn\u2019t even think venture is that important today, the two venture capitalists on the panel &#8212; Brackeen and Thomas &#8212; were good sports about the future of the asset class on which they have bet their careers.<\/p>\n<blockquote><p><strong>Thomas:<\/strong> The IPOs just keep on coming, and they keep getting bigger. It\u2019s crazy. I think that there is recreating an immense amount of wealth, and that we need to be thoughtful, we need to be careful. And we need to be just considerate of that fact. And so I plan to be in venture for the next 10 years. But I I think, to Astrid\u2019s point, we are not the only ones on the island. We are connected to all of these other different capital structures, and different communities. But my bet is still here. <strong>(Timestamp 25:14) <\/strong><\/p>\n<p><strong>Brackeen:<\/strong> Capital will continue to play a large role in capitalism, because the two are hand in hand. And venture capital is a version of that. Watch what we do. To see billions of dollars go into these geographies, these communities, these groups, the value creation is outrageous. Morgan Stanley, and others say that racism and sexism cost this country somewhere between $4 trillion and $16 trillion in kind of untapped value. So venture capital can be a key lever in opening that faucet. <strong>(Timestamp: 25:52)<\/strong><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<ul>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/03\/venture-capital-is-going-to-get-even-bigger-faster-and-more-expensive-this-year\/\">Venture capital is going to get even bigger, faster and more expensive this year<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/01\/21\/lame-lps-founder-referenceability-and-the-future-of-vc-signaling\/\"> Lame LPs, founder referenceability and the future of VC signaling<\/a><\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<p><span class=\"embed-youtube embed breakout embed--video\" style=\"text-align:center; display: block;\"><iframe class='youtube-player' width='640' height='360' src='https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/embed\/XXgr2a_su4s?version=3&#038;rel=1&#038;showsearch=0&#038;showinfo=1&#038;iv_load_policy=1&#038;fs=1&#038;hl=en-US&#038;autohide=2&#038;wmode=transparent' allowfullscreen='true' style='border:0;' sandbox='allow-scripts allow-same-origin allow-popups allow-presentation'><\/iframe><\/span><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/otter.ai\/u\/NwS2G1_Oe5NvNKaQvpEnccKVNy8\">You can read the entire transcript here.<\/a><\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p><em><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/26\/techcrunch-early-stage-is-the-startup-bootcamp-youve-always-needed\/?tpcc=ECTW2020\">Early Stage<\/a> is the premier &#8220;how-to&#8221; event for startup entrepreneurs and investors. You\u2019ll hear firsthand how some of the most successful founders and VCs build their businesses, raise money and manage their portfolios. We\u2019ll cover every aspect of company building: Fundraising, recruiting, sales, product-market fit, PR, marketing and brand building. Each session also has audience participation built-in &#8212; there\u2019s ample time included for audience questions and discussion.<\/em><\/p>\n<p>\t<iframe\n\t\t\tid=\"wpcom-iframe-dde292b93a5f3017145419dd51bb9fce\"\n\t\t\twidth=\"99%\"\n\t\t\theight=\"1500\"\n\t\t\tsrc=\"https:\/\/tcprotectedembed.com\/protected-iframe\/dde292b93a5f3017145419dd51bb9fce\"\n\t\t\tscrolling=\"true\"\n\t\t\tframeborder=\"0\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"wpcom-protected-iframe\"\n\t>\n\t<\/iframe>\n\t<script Sessions: Justice 2021","slug":"tc-sessions-justice-2021","taxonomy":"tc_event","rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event\/576821871"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/tc_event"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event\/449559507"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tc_event=576821871"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_events?tc_event=576821871"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tc_event=576821871"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}]]}},{"id":2122262,"date":"2021-03-08T07:46:40","date_gmt":"2021-03-08T15:46:40","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2122262"},"modified":"2021-03-08T11:34:30","modified_gmt":"2021-03-08T19:34:30","slug":"celebs-like-rob-dyrdek-joe-jonas-and-travis-barker-are-backing-the-nootropic-nosh-company-mindright","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/celebs-like-rob-dyrdek-joe-jonas-and-travis-barker-are-backing-the-nootropic-nosh-company-mindright\/","title":{"rendered":"Celebs like Rob Dyrdek, Joe Jonas and Travis Barker are backing the nootropic nosh company, Mindright"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">It was only a matter of time before someone married the nascent nootropic supplements for brain health to the snack bar craze that continues to attract dollars and exits.<\/p>\n<p>That time is apparently now, as Rob Dyrdek, the MTV-famous celebrity, pro-skater and entrepreneur, and Chris Bernard announce a new investment in the company they co-founded, <a href=\"http:\/\/www.getmindright.com\/\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Mindright<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, alongside celebrity investors including Joe Jonas, Travis Barker and The Profit&#8217;s Marcus Lemonis.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p>&#8220;When we started down the path of condition-specific food and beverage&#8230; we started doing a lot of research into the nootropics and adaptogens space,&#8221; said co-founder Bernard. Working with a food scientist who did not want to be named (which isn&#8217;t sketchy at all), Dyrdek and Bernard were introduced to several companies producing ashwagandha, which the two had settled on as the new key ingredient in their snack bars.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Along with ginseng and cordyceps mushrooms, the company has a trifecta of new (and old) supplements that have taken the nutraceutical world by storm.<\/p>\n<p>Bernard had initially approached the <a href=\"https:\/\/dyrdekmachine.com\/\">Dyrdek Machine<\/a> group about another product, but the company was too far along and not something that Dyrdek felt passionate about backing. The story changed when Bernard returned with plans for this nootropic nosh.<\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">&#8220;[Bernard] brought back the concept of the path of what\u2019s evolved from functional foods and probiotics and collagen and sort of the mental health and adaptogen and the supplement world and said here\u2019s how to merge these,&#8221; Dyrdek said of Bernard&#8217;s second pitch. &#8220;It was a home-run for us. Our process is supporting a solopreneur where we help shape and build the company together and provide the outsourced resources. We fund the development of the idea to go to the capital markets.&#8221;<\/span><\/p>\n<p>So far, Dyrdek and his team have made 15 investments in consumer and entertainment businesses, and five of those business have since been acquired.<\/p>\n<p>Most deals from Dyrdek Machine follow a similar trajectory. The firm becomes a co-founder and shares common stock and then negotiate a preferred equity investment for the capital infusion. Typically those deals range from $250,000 to $500,000.<\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">&#8220;We co-found it and we share that common share class and our first money is preferred and pick a valuation that balances out the deal,&#8221; Dyrdek said. &#8220;How much equity do we want to develop it with you is what we negotiate with that initial capital.&#8221;<\/span><\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2122278\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2122278\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2122278\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Dyrdek.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1024\" height=\"683\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Dyrdek.jpg 6720w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Dyrdek.jpg?resize=150,100 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Dyrdek.jpg?resize=300,200 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Dyrdek.jpg?resize=768,512 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Dyrdek.jpg?resize=680,453 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Dyrdek.jpg?resize=1536,1024 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Dyrdek.jpg?resize=2048,1365 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/Dyrdek.jpg?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2122278\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Portrait of Rob Dyrdek, founder of <a href=\"https:\/\/dyrdekmachine.com\/\">Dyrdek Machine<\/a>. Image Credits: Dyrdek Machine<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Dyrdek describes his investment firm as founder-driven and market agnostic. &#8220;We want a well-rounded, multi-dimensional founder and then we look at the market and how do we evolve it into something that has a larger, broader appeal,&#8221; Dyrdek said. &#8220;Rather than chasing down nootropics, we found that &#8216;good mood&#8217; was the important thing to the consumer base. That&#8217;s why we drove &#8216;Good mood superfood.&#8217; &#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Bernard&#8217;s faith in Dyrdek&#8217;s ability to move the business forward has been proven in the evolution of other companies in the firm&#8217;s portfolio. Dyrdek pointed to Outstanding Foods, another investment, which he said had recently closed a $10 million round at a $100 million valuation. Another startup in the portfolio, Momentous, a supplement manufacturer, also closed on a big round recently after raising $5 million in 2019, Dyrdek said.<\/p>\n<p>For Mindright, Dyrdek&#8217;s involvement brought in other celebrity names once they tried the product. The company counts Joe Jonas and Travis Barker among its seed investors.<\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">&#8220;They were excited to get involved in this because they believed in what we took the time to create,&#8221; Bernard said.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"Q6CrvAGfaa\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/08\/07\/iot-and-data-science-will-boost-foodtech-in-the-post-pandemic-era\/\">IoT and data science will boost foodtech in the post-pandemic era<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;IoT and data science will boost foodtech in the post-pandemic era&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/08\/07\/iot-and-data-science-will-boost-foodtech-in-the-post-pandemic-era\/embed\/#?secret=Q6CrvAGfaa\" data-secret=\"Q6CrvAGfaa\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>It was only a matter of time before someone married the nascent nootropic supplements for brain health to the snack bar craze that continues to attract dollars and exits. That time is apparently now, as Rob Dyrdek, the MTV-famous celebrity, pro-skater and entrepreneur, and Chris Bernard announce a new investment in the company they co-founded, \/","name":"Startups","slug":"startups","taxonomy":"category","parent":0,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/20429"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=20429"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=20429"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=20429"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":17396,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tc\/","name":"TC","slug":"tc","taxonomy":"category","parent":0,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/17396"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=17396"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":586,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/food\/","name":"food","slug":"food","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/586"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=586"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=586"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=586"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=586"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":289592,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/founder\/","name":"founder","slug":"founder","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/289592"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=289592"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=289592"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=289592"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=289592"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":449557089,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/health\/","name":"Health","slug":"health","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449557089"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449557089"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449557089"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449557089"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449557089"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":449553805,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/rob-dyrdek\/","name":"rob dyrdek","slug":"rob-dyrdek","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449553805"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449553805"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449553805"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449553805"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449553805"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":449557042,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/startups\/","name":"Startups","slug":"startups","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449557042"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449557042"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2119188,"date":"2021-03-08T07:30:05","date_gmt":"2021-03-08T15:30:05","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2119188"},"modified":"2021-03-08T11:23:54","modified_gmt":"2021-03-08T19:23:54","slug":"the-path-forward-for-essential-workers","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/08\/the-path-forward-for-essential-workers\/","title":{"rendered":"The path forward for essential workers"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">Gig workers and<\/span> warehouse workers have become essential in a pandemic-ravaged economy. In California, a law went into effect earlier this year that makes gig workers independent contractors. Meanwhile, Amazon warehouse workers in Alabama are actively seeking to form a union to ensure better protections at the workplace.<\/p>\n<p>At TC Sessions: Justice, I spoke with Gig Workers Collective co-founder and organizer Vanessa Bain, The Congress of Essential Workers founder and former Amazon warehouse worker Christian Smalls and National Council for Occupational Safety and Health Co-Executive Director Jessica E. Martinez about what\u2019s next for gig workers and tech\u2019s contractor workforce, and what battles lie ahead for these essential workers.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<h3>On the Amazon union drive<\/h3>\n<p>Amazon warehouse workers in Bessemer, Alabama are in the midst of a <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/07\/amazon-warehouse-workers-begin-historic-vote-to-unionize\/\">historic union drive<\/a>. Smalls, who was fired from his job at an Amazon warehouse in Staten Island last year after speaking out about the lack of personal protective equipment, told me he recently spent a few days in Bessemer.<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>The building opened up when coronavirus started. When New York City became the epicenter, that&#8217;s when the Bessemer facility opened up. So the union got a head start on talking to workers. So that&#8217;s a gem for anybody or any union that plans on trying to unionize the building &#8212; that you have a facility in your community that&#8217;s about to open up, when opening, that&#8217;s the best time to connect with workers. That&#8217;s what happened last year. And as a result, the workers had seen what happened to the workers that were unprotected and they don&#8217;t want that. They want better for themselves. And they rightfully deserve that, especially in Alabama. It&#8217;s a right to work state, a state with no state minimum, obviously a red state. So I think it&#8217;s a lot of intangibles against them. But these workers now see the window of opportunity for change systemically. <strong><em>(Timestamp: 4:40)<\/em><\/strong><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>Meanwhile, President Biden recently came out in support of the unionizing efforts in Bessemer.<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>I would hope that he is a man of his word. He&#8217;s a pro-union guy. He ran his campaign off of that, saying he&#8217;s a union guy and unions need to be strong, and he supports unions all the way. It was powerful to see that the president, the man, the highest plateau in the country, supports the union. <em><strong>(Timestamp: 13:11)<\/strong><\/em><\/p>\n<p>[&#8230;] But once again, like Vanessa said, I don&#8217;t put all my eggs in that basket either. I just want to hold him accountable. Make sure that, you know, we see this all the way through to the end. Even if Alabama is not successful, if we were to try again, in other locations, other parts of the country, that we have the support of the highest power in the country, that is the most powerful thing that will resonate with workers. So it&#8217;s good to see that it&#8217;s happening now. <em><strong>(Timestamp: 14:17)<\/strong><\/em><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<ul>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/07\/amazon-warehouse-workers-begin-historic-vote-to-unionize\/\">Amazon warehouse workers to begin historic vote to unionize<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/11\/12\/amazon-faces-lawsuit-alleging-failure-to-provide-ppe-to-workers-during-pandemic\/\">Amazon faces lawsuit alleging failure to provide PPE to workers during pandemic<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/17\/amazon-ny-ag-lawsuit\/\">NY AG sues Amazon over treatment of warehouse workers<\/a><\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<hr \/>\n<h3>On the effects of Prop 22<\/h3>\n<p>Already, Prop 22 has affected industries outside of tech. In December, supermarket chain Albertsons began replacing delivery drivers with contractors and hundreds of employees in California were swapped for DoorDash workers, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.bloomberg.com\/news\/features\/2021-02-17\/gig-economy-coming-for-millions-of-u-s-jobs-after-california-s-uber-lyft-vote?sref=gni836kR\">Bloomberg reported<\/a>. Meanwhile, tech companies have spoken about implementing Prop 22-like legislation in other parts of the country. Martinez described how some California residents who voted to pass Prop 22 thought they were supporting workers for better access to rights.<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>And unfortunately, you have workers who have possibly died. We have a California rideshare driver who died from COVID-19 last month. His independent classification means his family will receive no workers&#8217; compensation. That is a huge impact to workers and the reality of how it impacts day to day life for workers and in the midst of a pandemic. So I share that, because Prop 22 sets the tone, again, for what could happen nationally.\u00a0<strong><em>(Timestamp: 17:00)<\/em><\/strong><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>Meanwhile, Bain said she sees the passing of Prop 22 as a failure of &#8220;our entire structure of economy.&#8221;<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>And we have really allowed tech to run rampant under this pretense that somehow it&#8217;s innovative, and especially within the gig economy. I mean, it&#8217;s the opposite of innovative, right? Like it&#8217;s feudalism on your phone, right? It&#8217;s 1-800 dial listserv. So it&#8217;s like, they&#8217;re not doing anything new that justifies creating an entirely different classification of labor than existed before, which is what Prop 22 did, right? It literally created this category of marketplace contractor that retains neither the protections of an independent contractor nor an employee. And allowing, you know, companies to write their own laws in this way is a systemic failure. <strong><em>(Timestamp: 18:57)<\/em><\/strong><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<ul>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/12\/13\/an-even-bigger-battle-for-gig-worker-rights-is-on-the-horizon\/\">An even bigger battle for gig worker rights is on the horizon<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/05\/gig-workers-survey-san-francisco\/\">Gig workers in San Francisco are mostly people of color and many are immigrants, according to survey<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/16\/ex-postmates-vp-of-global-public-policy-on-the-future-of-gig-work\/\">Ex-Postmates VP of global public policy on the future of gig work<\/a><\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<hr \/>\n<h3>On the PRO Act<\/h3>\n<p>There&#8217;s legislation in the U.S. Senate right now that aims to make it easier for workers to organize and form unions in the country. The Protecting the Right to Organize Act seeks to change labor laws in favor of giving workers more power.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"TwVEjKJh2q\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/07\/24\/tech-at-work-black-gig-workers-speak-out-and-a-look-at-uber-commitment-to-being-anti-racist-and-facebooks-diversity-report\/\">Black gig workers speak out, Uber&#8217;s commitment to being anti-racist and Facebook&#8217;s diversity report<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Black gig workers speak out, Uber&#8217;s commitment to being anti-racist and Facebook&#8217;s diversity report&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/07\/24\/tech-at-work-black-gig-workers-speak-out-and-a-look-at-uber-commitment-to-being-anti-racist-and-facebooks-diversity-report\/embed\/#?secret=TwVEjKJh2q\" data-secret=\"TwVEjKJh2q\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>Bain spoke about the importance of getting the PRO Act across the line in light of the passing of Prop 22 in California.<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>These things shouldn&#8217;t be at the mercy of who happens to be, you know, held to a position. These are things that should be codified and enshrined really in law. And things that should be consistent and stable protections that people can rely on and count on.\u00a0<strong><em>(Timestamp: 20:22)<\/em><\/strong><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>Martinez explained how the PRO Act aligns with the <a href=\"https:\/\/nationalcosh.org\/sites\/default\/files\/2021-02%20National%20Agenda%20for%20Worker%20Safety%20and%20Health.pdf\">work she&#8217;s doing at COSH<\/a>. The organization recently released a national agenda for worker safety and health, along with some recommendations.<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>We want stronger safety laws, tougher enforcement, including a mandatory emergency standard to prevent the spread of infectious disease. And again, this is federally so if there is an ETS or an emergency [temporary] standard pass, it applies all over and impacts all kinds of workers, stronger protections against retaliation.\u00a0<strong><em>(Timestamp: 07:53)<\/em><\/strong><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>Martinez added:<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>Employers will funnel resources to try scare tactics to scare workers from organizing, demanding safer workplaces, job security, and so forth. [The agenda] also includes workers are included in all policy decisions. We believe strongly that workers, more than anyone, understand the job, know the solutions and controls to health and safety issues, and also equity and inclusion to end the misclassification and better protections for temporary gig workers. Paid sick and family leave for workers, also worker centered health protocols, including health for high-risk workers and getting access to vaccines. And we want to confront the workplace effects of climate change. Finally, also prevent chemical catastrophes and harmful exposure. [&#8230;] With that said, this is not working in isolation. It works in collaboration with laws, we&#8217;re hoping that will pass, such as the PRO Act, allowing workers to gain bargaining power when organizing, essentially giving them the ability to negotiate with the employer to get access to benefits again, such as some job security paid sick leave, workers comp and so forth. <strong><em>(Timestamp: 8:23)<\/em><\/strong><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><span data-sheets-value=\"{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;&quot;}\" data-sheets-userformat=\"{&quot;2&quot;:12801,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;12&quot;:0,&quot;15&quot;:&quot;Open Sans&quot;,&quot;16&quot;:12}\"> <div embedded-video-placeholder=\"603fd6c1fb2e1e3363ff491c\" post-id=\"2120505\"><\/div> <\/span><\/p>\n<p>You can read the <a href=\"https:\/\/otter.ai\/u\/UGTB23Mu9JiPv-cYY5YHKQ3IZOA\">entire transcript here<\/a>.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p><em><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/26\/techcrunch-early-stage-is-the-startup-bootcamp-youve-always-needed\/?tpcc=ECTW2020\">Early Stage<\/a> is the premier &#8220;how-to&#8221; event for startup entrepreneurs and investors. You\u2019ll hear firsthand how some of the most successful founders and VCs build their businesses, raise money and manage their portfolios. We\u2019ll cover every aspect of company building: Fundraising, recruiting, sales, product-market fit, PR, marketing and brand building. Each session also has audience participation built-in &#8212; there\u2019s ample time included for audience questions and discussion.<\/em><\/p>\n<p>\t<iframe\n\t\t\tid=\"wpcom-iframe-dde292b93a5f3017145419dd51bb9fce\"\n\t\t\twidth=\"99%\"\n\t\t\theight=\"1500\"\n\t\t\tsrc=\"https:\/\/tcprotectedembed.com\/protected-iframe\/dde292b93a5f3017145419dd51bb9fce\"\n\t\t\tscrolling=\"true\"\n\t\t\tframeborder=\"0\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"wpcom-protected-iframe\"\n\t>\n\t<\/iframe>\n\t<script TechCrunch&#8217;s free virtual Miami meetup on March 11"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">TechCrunch is hosting a small virtual meetup this Thursday centered around Miami. We hope you can attend. It&#8217;s free.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/hopin.com\/events\/techcrunch-miami\">This is our first (virtual) field trip to Miami<\/a>. Even though we can\u2019t be there physically right now, it\u2019ll sure feel like we are. All lights will be shining on the Magic City. The area is quickly transforming thanks to active investors, interesting companies, a Twitter-proficient mayor and beautifully scenic living.<\/p>\n<p>If you\u2019re interested in what\u2019s happening in Miami in general, seeking out a new, up-and-coming city to live in, looking for cool companies and talented founders to invest in, then you\u2019ll want to <a href=\"https:\/\/hopin.com\/events\/techcrunch-miami\">register<\/a> and drop March 11 on your calendar. This is a virtual event, but space is still limited, so register early.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Here\u2019s just some of what you can expect:<\/p>\n<ul>\n<li>Networking &#8211; It\u2019s what you can always count on us for. Companies are started and deals get done at TechCrunch events (yes, even the virtual ones!).<\/li>\n<li>Pitch-off &#8211; We\u2019re going to tap into the local tech scene in Miami and bring on some VCs to take a look at\u00a0 your pitches. They\u2019ll give you feedback live from the stage. Sign up to pitch by <a href=\"https:\/\/oathtechevents.typeform.com\/to\/kZ4l728t\">filling out this form<\/a>.<\/li>\n<li>Panels &#8211; Meet the movers and shakers up close and personal. Hear about their journey, ask them questions and find out what\u2019s special to them about Miami.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<p>All along the way we\u2019ll be asking for your feedback by way of polls, Q&amp;As and surveys. We want to hear from everyone who lives in the birthplace of sunscreen, and we\u2019re looking to you for suggestions on folks who should be getting all of the attention we can throw at them on March 11. Drop suggestions in the comments below.<\/p>\n<p>It\u2019s going to be one to remember, and it\u2019s the perfect setup for when we can safely crash the city in person again!<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"xFirjM0Gyi\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/03\/have-a-startup-in-miami-apply-to-pitch-at-techcrunchs-miami-virtual-meetup\/\">Have a startup in Miami? Crunch Live: Mayfield and Poshmark"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><em>Wednesday, March 24 at 11:30am PT \/ 2:30pm ET<\/em><\/p>\n<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Poshmark raised upwards of $150 million before filing to go public in 2019. Today, it has a market cap north of $5 billion. Mayfield\u2019s Navin Chaddha led the company\u2019s Series A all the way back in 2011, back when Poshmark was called Gosh Posh. Then the duo will take a look at pitch decks submitted by audience members.<\/p>\n<p><a class=\"button button--gold-gradient button--secondary\" href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/18\/check-out-the-incredible-speakers-joining-us-on-extra-crunch-live-in-march\/\">Extra Crunch members click for dial in details<\/a><\/p>\n<p><a class=\"button button--green-gradient button--primary\" href=\"https:\/\/hopin.com\/events\/extra-crunch-live-mayfield-and-poshmark\">Buy Tickets<\/a><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Wednesday, March 24 at 11:30am PT \/ 2:30pm ET Poshmark raised upwards of $150 million before filing to go public in 2019. Today, it has a market cap north of $5 billion. Mayfield\u2019s Navin Chaddha led the company\u2019s Series A all the way back in 2011, back when Poshmark was called Gosh Posh. Hear Chaddha [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"featured_media":2116169,"parent":0,"menu_order":0,"template":"","tc_event":[576857625],"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"agenda":{"sessionTypes":[],"sessionData":[{"date":"24 March","sessions":[{"guid":"6943054960341e40bd943","start":"11:30 am","end":"1:30 pm","description":"","title":"Extra Crunch Live: Mayfield and Poshmark","videoUrl":"","sessionTypeId":false,"speakers":[],"sponsors":[],"tags":[]}]}]},"bannerImageURL":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/04\/gian-d-359346-unsplash.jpg","bannerTextStyle":"light","description":"The startup world\u00a0is going through yet another evolution. A few years ago, VCs were focused on growth over profitability. Now, making money is just as important, if not more, than sheer growth. And we\u2019re in the midst of a global pandemic, which has brought the economy to a crawl and forced entrepreneurs to rethink both their short and long-term priorities.\n\nStartups want to hear from the voices they trust for guidance on how to navigate this difficult situation. That\u2019s why we\u2019re excited to introduce Extra Crunch Live, a virtual speaker series complete with live Q&A exclusive for Extra Crunch members.","blocks":[{"text":"<p><em>Wednesday, March 24 at 11:30am PT \/ 2:30pm ET<\/em><\/p><p>Poshmark raised upwards of $150 million before filing to go public in 2019. Today, it has a market cap north of $5 billion. Mayfield's Navin Chaddha led the company's Series A all the way back in 2011, back when Poshmark was called Gosh Posh. Hear Chaddha and Poshmark founder Manish Chandra discuss a decade of growth, and walk us through how they came together more than ten years ago. Then the duo will take a look at pitch decks submitted by audience members.<\/p><p><a class=\"button button--gold-gradient button--secondary\" href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/18\/check-out-the-incredible-speakers-joining-us-on-extra-crunch-live-in-march\/\">Extra Crunch members click for dial in details<\/a><\/p><p><a class=\"button button--green-gradient button--primary\" href=\"https:\/\/hopin.com\/events\/extra-crunch-live-mayfield-and-poshmark\">Buy Tickets<\/a><\/p>","title":"Extra Crunch Live: Mayfield and Poshmark","type":"text","panels_info":{"class":"TC\\Page_Builder\\TinyMCE\\Widget","grid":0,"cell":0,"id":0,"style":{"background_image_attachment":false,"background_display":"tile"}},"uid":"a6e3dc43-3c76-49b8-a66c-a9940945bcbc","backgroundImageURL":null},{"uid":"14da3361-2a11-4379-92dc-275f25d264d1","panels_info":{"class":"TC\\Page_Builder\\Events\\Agenda_Block","raw":false,"grid":0,"cell":0,"id":1},"type":"event-agenda"}],"blockMetadata":{"agenda":{"title":""},"speakers":{"title":""},"sponsors":{"title":""},"newsletter":{"title":"","content":""},"video":{"title":""}},"blockNavigation":null,"videoCarouselPlaylistID":"","livestreams":false,"promotionReelHash":"","eventStatus":"pre","exhibitorData":[],"marketingOffers":{"countdown":{"display":false},"ctaBlock":{"display":false}},"marketoID":"","navigation":{"blocks":[{"text":"<p><em>Wednesday, March 24 at 11:30am PT \/ 2:30pm ET<\/em><\/p><p>Poshmark raised upwards of $150 million before filing to go public in 2019. You will be asked to provide your billing information that will be shown on the invoice and once you finalize registration, you'll be emailed an invoice with instructions on how to pay via wire.<\/p>\n<p>All wire payments will need to be <strong>RECEIVED<\/strong>\u00a0by our Accounts Receivable's team no later than September 1, 2020 or any pass reservations will be cancelled. Please note that it sometimes takes up to 2-3 weeks for the Accounts Receivable team to verify payment so submit your payments as soon as possible to ensure you meet this deadline before your pass is cancelled.
